editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: HE'S MUCH TO BLAME, A COMEDY: IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER ROW.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE author of HE'S MUCH TO BLAME is in ſome ſmall degree indebted to Le Complaiſant, a comedy attributed to Monſieur De Ferriol Pont-de-Veyle, and to the tragedy of Clavigo by Goethe.

lg.l: PROLOGUES, in theſe ſagacious days, muſt not
Repeat the ſtory; and betray the plot:
For deep laid plots we ſometimes have, no doubt:
'Tis pity you can't always find them out:
The ſecret muſt be kept; and not be told:
In this, at leaſt, we beat the bards of old:
We can't endure our meaning you ſhould gueſs,
And here again we boaſt complete ſucceſs:
Cautious leſt you the myſtery ſhould diſcover,
We keep you in the dark—till all is over.
Since theſe important points we muſt not name,
The title let's diſcuſs: He's much▪to blame!
To blame? Ay, ſurely; very much! But who.
The author. Well, that's nothing very new.
And what does blame induce? Why puniſhment.
Raſhly we ſin and leiſurely repent.
Lured by that tempting bait a nine nights' bonus,
Theſe ſcribbling ſinners multiply upon us!
Then prologues write; to whine, cajole, and tickle:
Begging you'll burn the rod you've laid in pickle.
Shielding himſelf by theſe and ſuch like arts,
He hopes to hurl with ſurer aim his darts.
But ſtrike and cry, when we receive a blow,
Is arrant cowardice! I told him ſo.
He's mad, who would the field of battle tread;
Unleſs he hoped to have a broken head.
There's honor in ſuch ſcars—he'll win and wear it▪
Then give him honor plenty! Never ſpare it.
But, ſhould it be your pleaſure not to quarrel,
He'll very kindly bear his load of laurel.

list.item: Maſter of the Hotel, Mr. Thompſon.

div.head: HE'S MUCH TO BLAME, A COMEDY.
SCENE I.— Ringing heard. The hall of a hotel, with a ſpacious ſtair-caſe.
div.stage: Enter the MASTER and HEAD WAITER meeting.

sp.speaker: MASTER.
sp.p: WHY where are all the fellows, Jenkins? Don't you hear the bell No. 9?

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Tom is gone up to anſwer it, ſir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Who occupies that apartment?

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: The handſome youth and girl, that arrived late laſt night.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Juſt as I was going to bed?

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: He is quite a boy.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Razor has never robbed him of a hair.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Some ſtripling, perhaps, that has run away with his mother's maid.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: They ordered ſeparate beds.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Well, ſee what they want.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p:
And, harkye, be attentive the moment you hear Lord and Lady Vibrate, or their daughter,
ſtirring. People of quality muſt never be neglected.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Oh, no, ſir—Here is Dr. Goſterman.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Good morrow, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Coot morgen, my tear friend. Is de Fiprate family fiſible to ſee?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My lordtſhip und my latyſhip vas ſharge me to be mit dem betime.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: You are a great favourite there, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. Dat I am efery vhere.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: You act in a double capacity: phyſician, and privy counſellor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und I am as better in de von as in de oder.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Why ay, Doctor, you have a ſmooth pleaſant manner.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. Dat is my vay. I mix de ſyrup mit all my preſcription.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you are a uſeful perſon.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. Dat is my vay. I leave Yarmany und I com at Englandt mit little money, und great cunning in de art, und de ſcience. I ſhall af de eſſence, und de cream, und de balſam, und de ſyrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earſe, und de ſea, und all dat vas ſubject under my command. So I make de nation benefit▪ und myſelf riſh. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Yes; you can tickle the guineas into your pocket.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: You have had many patients?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. I af cure touſand und touſand! Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: And how many have you killed, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Der Teufel, ſair! Kill? Ven my patient vas die, dat vas Nature dat vas kill. Ven dey vas cure, dat vas Dr. Von Goſtermans. Dat is my vay. No, ſair! Dr. Von Goſtermans vas kill himſelf, dat oder people may live.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: How do you mean kill yourſelf, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Der Teufel, ſair! Vas I not be call here? Vas I not be call dere? Vas I not be call efery vhere? I af hundert und touſand patient dat die efery day, till I vas com. So I vas drive to de city; und dere I vas meet my beſten friend, de gout, de apoplexy, und de aſthmatica: und den I vas drive to de inn of court, und de lawyer; und dere I vas find more of my beſten friend; de hydropica, de rheumatica, und de paralytica.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: What, Doctor! The lawyers and inn • of court paralytic?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: I wiſh they were, with all my ſoul!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und den I vas drive und make my reverence mit de lordt, und mit de duke, und mit de grandee; und dere I vas meet moſh oder of my beſten friend; de hypochondrica, de ſpaſmodica, de hyſterica, de maraſma, de morbid affection, de tremor, und de miſt before de eye.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Morbid affections, tremors, and miſts before the eyes, the diſeaſes of the great?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. Und dey vas grow vorſe und vorſe efery day.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Well, well, they have choſen a ſkilful doctor!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Ya, ſair. I ſhall do all deir buſineſs, efery
von. Dat is my vay. I ſhall af de eſſence, und de cream, und de balſam, und de ſyrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earſe, und de ſea, und all dat vas ſubject under my command. Dat is my vay. Bote dat is as noting at all. Ah ſa, my liebſte: you vas my beſten friend. You make me acquaint myſelf mit all de patient dat vas come to your houſe; and ſo I vas your beſten friend, und I vas gif de phyſic for yourſelf, und de phyſic for your ſhile, und de phyſic for your vife.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: For which my wife will never more thank you, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: No: your vife vas die, und you vas tank me yourſelf. So now you tell me: Af you any new cuſtomer dat vas com?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Yes: a youth, and a girl that looks like a waiting maid, arrived late laſt night.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vhich it vas a perſon of grandeur?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Oh no; wholly unattended.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ah! Vhich it vas a lofing couple, den?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: It ſeems not.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: A poy und a vaiting vomans! Dere ſhall be ſometing myſtery in dat.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: So I think. Here comes the girl.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ah! Let me do: I ſhall talk to her. I ſhall begin by make acquaintance mit her.

div.head: SCENE III. Enter LUCY down the ſtaircaſe.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, deſire the waiter to make haſte with breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Here, Jenkins! Breakfaſt to No. 9! Be quick!

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: (Without) Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Tea or coffee, madam?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Tea.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: How you do, my tear? You vas pretty young frau: fery pretty girl, my tear. Perhaps you vas ſtranger, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Perhaps I am.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah! Vat is your name, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That which my Godmother gave me.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Your maſtair af made de long yourney, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Has he?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: From vat country you com, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I aſk, from vat country you com, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Aſk again.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: From de town of—Ha!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Ay. How do you call it?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is vat I vant you ſhall tell?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I ſee you do.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Your maſtair is fery young, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Thank you, ſir.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: For vat you tank me?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: For your news.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah, ah! You are fery vitty und pretty, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: More news. Thank you again.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vat vas you call de young yentleman's name?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I will aſk, and ſend you word.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: How long ſhall he be ſtay in town?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Till he goes into the country.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vat is your capacity, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Like yours, little enough.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: You not underſtandt me, my tear. Vat is your poſt, your office?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: To anſwer rude queſtions.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Your maſtair is man of family?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Yes. He had a father, and mother, and uncles, and aunts.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und tey vas tead?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I am not a tombſtone.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Com, com, my tear, let you make me anſwer.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Anan?

div.stage: Enter WAITER.

sp.speaker: WAIT.
sp.p: Here is the breakfaſt, madam.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Take it up ſtairs.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Lucy and Waiter up the ſtaircaſe.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Der Teufel! A cunning yipſey! She has make me raiſe my curioſity. (Calls.) My tear! My tear! Com pack, my tear! (Lucy returns) Do my compliment to your maſtair, und I ſhall make me moſh happy if I ſhall af de honeur to make me acquaintance mit him. My name is call Dr. Von Goſtermans. I ſhall af de eſſence, und de cream, und de balſam, und de ſyrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earſe, und de ſea, und all dat vas ſubject under my command. I ſhall af de beſt recommendation for de honeſt Docteur dat vas poſſible. My Lordt und my Laty Fiprate vas my beſten friend. I vas practice mit all de piggeſt family in de uniferſe. Docteur Von Goſtermans vas know efery poty; und efery poty vas know Docteur Von Goſtermans. You tell him dat, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Tell him that? I cannot remember half of it! Are you, ſir, acquainted with Lord Vibrate's family?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my tear. I vas make friendſhip mit dem more as many year.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: And do you know where they are?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: To be ſure he does. They are in this—

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (Aſide to Maſter.) Huſh! Silence your tongue! Dere is ſometing myſtery. (Aloud.) If you ſhall make me introduce to your maſtair, my tear, I ſhall tell him efery ting und more as dat, my tear. Vill you, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I will go and enquire.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Tank you, my tear. You are fery pretty girl, my tear: fery vitty pretty—Ah! You are ſo ſly cunning little yipſey, my tear. Ah ah! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A chamber. MARIA in man's clothes with a letter in her hand and walking with anxiety. The Waiter enters and leaves the breakfaſt. She then reads.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: "Dear ſiſter, The letter I now write is almoſt needleſs, for I ſhall leave Italy and follow it immediately; having at laſt obtained intelligence of your faithleſs lover. I am ſorry to inform you that, in addition to your unpardonable wrongs, I have my own to vindicate. But I have threatened too long. You have heard of the Earl of Vibrate. He and his family are by this arrived in England; your betrayer accompanies them, and I am in cloſe purſuit. PAUL DELAVAL."

In what will this end? Muſt they meet? Muſt they fight? Muſt one or both of them fall? Oh horror! Shall I be the cauſe of murder? And whoſe blood is to be ſpilled? That of the moſt generous of brothers, or of the man on whom my firſt and laſt affections have been fixed! Is there no ſafety; no means?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Why look here now, madam, you are letting the breakfaſt grow cold! You have been reading that letter again. I do believe I ſhall never get you to eat any more. Come now, pray do take ſome of this French roll; and I'll pour out the tea. Do! Pray do! Pray do!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I cannot eat, Lucy: I am eaten. Terror and deſpair are devouring me.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Dear! Dear! What will all this come to? Did not you promiſe me that, as ſoon as you had got ſafe to London in your diſguiſe, you would be better?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Can it be? My kind, my gentle, my true hearted George!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: True hearted! No no, madam, he was never true hearted: or he could not ſo ſoon have changed, becauſe his ill fortune changed to good. Every body knows true love never changes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: What have I done? How have I offended? His careſſes, his proteſtations, his tender endearments! Is then the man in whom my ſoul was wrapt a vil—Oh!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I declare, madam, if you take on this way, you will break my heart as well as your own. Beſide, you forget all the while what you put on this dreſs and came up to London for.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh no. It was if poſſible to prevent miſchief! Murder!—They have never met. They do not know each other. But how ſhall I diſcover Sir George? Of whom ſhall I enquire?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: If you would but eat your breakfaſt, I do think I could put you in the way.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: By what means?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Will you eat your breakfaſt, then?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I cannot eat. Speak.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Why I have juſt been talking to an outlandiſh comical Doctor, that ſays he is acquainted with Lord Vibrate.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Indeed! Where is this Doctor?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: He is waiting without: for I knew you would wiſh to ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Shew him in immediately.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I'll tell him you are not well; which is but too true; though you muſt remember, madam, you are a man. So dry your eyes, forget your miſfortunes, and, there, cock your hat, a that faſhion, and try to ſwagger a little; or you will be found out. You ſtand ſo like a ſtatue, and look ſo pitiful! Lord, that's not the way! If you are timorſome, and ſilent, and baſhful, nobody on earth will take you for a youth of fortune and faſhion.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (In revery.) If they ſhould meet! Heavens! They muſt not.

div.head: SCENE VI. Re-enter LUCY and DOCTOR.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: My maſter is not very well: he eats neither breakfaſt, dinner nor ſupper, and gets no ſleep.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He noder eat, noder drink, noder ſleep! Dat is pad! Fery pad! But dat it as noting at all, my tear. Let me do. You ſhall ſee preſently py and py vat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Your ſervant, ſir.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Sair, I vas your moſh obliſhe fery omple ſairfant, ſair. My name is call Dr. Von Goſtermans.
I ſhall af de beſt recommendation for de honeſt Docteur dat vas poſſible. I vas practice mit all de piggeſt family in de uniferſe. Docteur Von Goſtermans is know efery pody; und efery pody is know Dr. Von Goſtermans. De pretty coquine yung frau tell me dat you not fery fell. You not eat, you not drink, you not ſleep. Dat is pad! Fery pad! Bote dat is as noting at all. You tell me de diagnoſtic und de prognoſtic of all vat you vill ail; und I ſhall make you preſcripe for de anodyne, oder de epipaſtic, oder de balſamic, oder de narcotic, oder de diaphoretic, oder de expectoratic, oder de reſtoratif, oder de emulſif, oder de inciſif; vhich is efery ting ſo ſhveet und ſo delectable as all vat is poſſible.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Your pardon, ſir, but I wiſh to ſee you on buſineſs of another nature.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ah! Someting of de prifate affair! Dat is coot. I ſhall be as better for dat as for de oder. I vas know de vorl. I vas know efery pody; und efery pody vas know me. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Perhaps then you happen to know Sir George Verſatile?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, Der Teufel, ſair! Ya, ya. Sair Shorge is my beſten friend. Vhich it vas ſix month dat he vas ſucceed to his title und eſtate; und den I vas make acquaintance mit him: dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But he has been abroad ſince.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Ya, ſair. Ven he vas poor, he vas fall in lofe mit fery pretty yung frau. Bote ſo ſoon as he vas pecome riſh paronet dat vas anoder ting! So
his relation und his friend vas ſent him to make de Gran tour.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And he was eaſily perſuaded.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. He vas vat you call fery coot nature: he vas alvay comply.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Compliance with him is more than a weakneſs: I fear it is a vice.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: So he vas make acquaintance mit Lordt und mit Laty Fiprate: und den he vas tink no more of de pretty yung frau, pecauſe he vas fall in lofe mit anoder.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Sir! Another! What other?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vat you ſhall ail, ſair? You ſhange coleur.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: With whom has he fallen in love?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Mit de taughter of Lordt Fiprate.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: With Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair: mit Laty Shane—My cot, ſair! vat you ſhall ail? You not make fall in lofe yourſelf mit Laty Shane?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: No, no—They are no doubt to be married.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Cot, ſair! you ſo pale as deaths—My Cot, you ſhall faint!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Faint, indeed! (Aſide) Bear up, madam. (Aloud) My maſter is too much of a man to faint. (Aſide) I'll run for a glaſs of water. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: The charming Lady▪ Jane—Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Lordt und my Laty Fiprate und my Laty Shane vas all in de houſe here.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: In this houſe?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And is Sir George here, too?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He is com und go alvay ſometime efery tay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Are they to be married?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Cot, ſair! you af de ague fit.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Are they to be married?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Laty Fiprate vas moſh incline to Sair Shorge; und my Lordt vas ſometime moſh incline too; und den he vas ſometime not moſh incline; und den he vas doubt; und den he vas do me de honeur to conſultate mit me.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And what is your advice?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Lordt Fiprate vas my beſten friends, und I vas adfice dat he ſhall do all as vat he pleaſe: und Sair Shorge vas my beſten friends too, und I vas adfice dat he ſhall do all as vat he pleaſe: und my Laty Fiprate vas petter as my beſten friends, und den I vas more adfice dat ſhe ſhall do all as vat ſhe pleaſe.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But Lady Jane had another lover?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. Mr. Delafal vas make lofe mit her. He vas com from de Eaſt Indie, und he vas lofe her fery moſh; und ſhe vas go mit de family to Italy, und my Laty Fiprate vas make acquaintance mit Sair Shorge, pecauſe he vas ſo moſh pleaſant und coot humeur, und he ſay all as vat ſhe ſay: vhich vas de vay to alvay make agréable.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Could you do me the favor to introduce me to Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. I ſhall do all as vat ſhall make agréable. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aſide to her miſtreſs) Oh, madam, don't be terrified, but I declare I have ſpilled almoſt all the water!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Alarmed) What is the matter?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: He is come!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Who? Sir George?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: No: don't be frightened: Mr. Delaval, from abroad.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My brother! Heavens! Did he ſee you?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: No. I had a▪glimpſe of him, and whiſked away juſt as he ſtepped out of the poſtchaiſe.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Should he meet me in this diſguiſe, what will he ſay?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Send away the Doctor, and let us lock ourſelves up.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (To the Doctor) I muſt beg you will excuſe me, ſir; but it is neceſſary at preſent I ſhould be alone. With your permiſſion, I will ſee you again in the afternoon; and, in the mean time— (Gives money)

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, ſair! I vas your moſh obliſhe fery omple ſairfant, ſair. I ſhall make you moſh more fiſit; und den you ſhall tell me de diagnoſtic und de prognoſtic of all vat you vill all.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Yes yes, another time.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und I ſhall af de eſſence, und de cream, und de balſam, und de ſyrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earſe, und de ſea, und all dat vas ſubject under my command.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: You have told us all that before.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und I ſhall make you preſcripe for de anodyne, oder de epipaſtic, oder de balſamic, oder de ſoporific, oder de narcotic, oder de diaphoretic, oder de expectoratic, oder de reſtoratif, oder de emulſif, oder de inciſif, vhich is efery ting ſo ſhveet und del • ctable as all vat is poſſible.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aſide) Was ever any thing ſo provoking?—Pray, ſir, make haſte.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: You ſhall make remembrance of Dr. Von Goſtermans. I am practice mit all de piggeſt family in de uniferſe. Sair, I vas your moſh obliſhe fery omple ſairfant, ſair. (The Doctor goes off talking, and Lucy locks the door while the ſcene changes.)

div.head: SCENE IX. The hall of the hotel.
div.stage: DELAVAL, WILLIAMS, MASTER and JENKINS.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Is the portmanteau ſafe?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: And the trunks?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: All right.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Have you paid the poſtillions?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: MASTER.
sp.p: (To Delaval) This way if you pleaſe, ſir. Jenkins!

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Coming, ſir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Shew the damaſk room. What will you pleaſe to have for breakfaſt, ſir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Bring tea, coffee, and new laid eggs.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: In a minute, ſir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (To W • l • iams) Obſerve the directions I gave you. Enquire, immediately, and find if the Vibrate family be in town?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I will be careful, ſir.—Hay?— (To Delaval going)—Sir! Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Look! Here comes Lord Vibrate's ſecretary!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (To Thompſon) Mr. Thompſon!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Delaval? I am heartily glad to ſee you in England!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Thank you, my good friend. But how is this? Where is the family? Where is Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I thought that would be your queſtion! They are all in this houſe.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I knew, when Lady Jane left Italy, your ſtay there would be ſhort.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Ay, ay! The follies and frenzies of the madman are viſible to all eyes, except his own.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I ſee you are diſſatisfied.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Tortured, till my thoughts and temper are ſo changed that I am almoſt as odious to myſelf as the world is become hateful to me.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I own, you have ſome cauſe.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Would my injuries were all! But there are other and ſtill deeper ſtabs. It is not yet ten months ſince I returned from India: my heart how light, my eve how cheerful, and my hand prompt at any commendable act. I could then be moved to joy, and ſorrow, and every ſympathiſing paſſion. Smiles and mock courteſy paſſed current on me, the word of man and woman was taken on truſt, and I lived in the ſunſhine of an open unſuſpecting ſoul. But I am now otherwiſe taught. I am changed. My better part is brutalized; and the wrongs that lie rankling here have ſtripped me of human affections, and made me almoſt ſavage.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: What can be ſaid? Patience is the—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
Talk not of patience: I muſt act. I
may then perhaps enquire whether I have acted rightly? But I muſt firſt ſee Lady Jane, and Lord Vibrate.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Shall I inform his lordſhip of your arrival?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: By no means. Having injured, he may wiſh not to ſee me: and I would not afford him time to invent excuſes, and avoid giving me a hearing. Though my wrongs muſt be endured, they ſhall be told.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I own, they are great.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Thoſe that you know are heavy; yet, ſevere as the ſtruggle would be, 'tis poſſible they might be huſhed to reſt: but there are others▪ which blood only can obliterate! which can only ſleep in death! Such is the road I muſt travel. Not long ſince nature was jocund, the azure heavens were bright, and pleaſure was in every path; but now darkneſs, fathomleſs gulphs, guilty terrors, and all the dreadful phantoms of meditated deſolation, lie before me. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: LORD VIBRATE at a table with a quarto volume reading.

sp.speaker: LORD VIBRATE.
sp.p:
THE ancient ſceptics doubted of every thing, affirmed nothing, and kept the judgment always in ſuſpenſe: All things, ſaid they, are equally indifferent, uncertain, and indeterminate. The mind is never to aſſent to any thing; that it may never be aſtoniſhed, or diſturbed, but enjoy
a perfect calm. (Riſes with important wiſdom in his looks) Such were the maxims of Pyrrho, and his diſciples; thoſe renowned ſages of antiquity! Well! And ſuch too have been my maxims, practically. All my life have I been wavering, uncertain, and indeterminate! A ſagacious ſceptic without knowing it; and as it were by inſtinct! It was but lately I diſcovered what a wiſe man I am! And yet it ſeems to me as if I were ſcarcely half wiſe enough, for I am told that I am to doubt of every thing which I find rather difficult. For example: that my wife Lady Vibrate is an extravagant rackety rantipole woman of faſhion, can I doubt that? No. That ſhe ſquanders my money, diſturbs my peace, and contradicts for contradiction's ſake, can I doubt that? No. Then have I not a daughter to marry, a law ſuit to begin, and a thouſand perplexing affairs ſo that I do not know which way to turn? Why all this appears true to me: but the ſceptics teach that appearances deceive, and that nothing is certain. I may be Lord Vibrate, or I may be the Grand Turk. Theſe doctrines are prodigiouſly deep. (Conſiders) But I muſt think of ſomething elſe juſt now. I have a thouſand things to do, and know as little where to begin as where they will end. Ay! All is uncertainty! (Rings) Harry! Edward!

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Did your lordſhip call?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Where are my ſervants? I want ſome of my plagues.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: They are ready at hand, my lord. Here is your lordſhip's ſecretary.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter MR. THOMPSON, and exit JENKINS.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What is the reaſon, Mr. Thompſon, that nobody waits? Here am I, fretting myſelf to a mummy for the good of my family, while every body about me is as drowſy as the court of common council after dinner! Have they taken laudanum? Are they in a lethargy? Are they all dead?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: If they were, your lordſhip would have the goodneſs to raiſe them.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Don't you know how many people I have to ſee, and places I have to go to?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why, did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then how can you ſay you don't know?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Becauſe I venture to preſume, my lord, you do not know yourſelf.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I am diſtracted with doubts. Harry!

div.head: SCENE IV. Enter Footman.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Did your lordſhip call?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Where are you all? What are you about? I think you have lived long enough with me to know my way.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord: we know it very well.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: If you are not more attentive, I'll diſcharge you every one.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Oh no: (Half aſide) you will not do that.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What are you muttering, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Only, my lord, that we know your way.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Order the coach at eleven.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No. Order it at one.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Come back! Order it in ten minutes, and remember I am not at home. Come back! Don't order it at all.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Muſt viſitors be admitted?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Yes. No. I cannot tell. I will conſider. Be within call. Thompſon!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Step to that picture dealer. I will have the Guido. Yet—'tis a great ſum! No—It is a maſter piece. I muſt have it. Why don't you go?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The picture is ſold, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Sold? Gone? Have I loſt it? This is always the way! I am for ever diſappointed. Harry!

div.stage: Re-enter Footman.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did you go with the meſſage to the ſtable keeper, laſt night?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Let me know when he comes.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: He will come no more, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Come no more?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: He ſays you never know your own mind, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Inſolent fellow!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Dr. Goſterman is below.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Admit him. Stay. I cannot ſee him yet. In half an hour. In ten minutes. By and by.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I muſt not waſte my time in theſe trifles. I muſt attend to this law buſineſs. I wiſh I could determine. What am I to do, Thompſon?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: In what, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The affair of the ejectment. If I once embroil myſelf in law, there will be no end; and if I do not the conſequences are ſtill worſe.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Then they are bad indeed, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange that I can come to no reſolution, on this ſubject.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Nor on any other.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I muſt decide this very day, or the time will be elapſed.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: A lawyer I ſhould ſuppoſe, my lord, would give you the beſt advice.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: How? Are you mad, Thompſon? A lawyer give good advice!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The preſent poſſeſſor has held the eſtate twenty years.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Not till tomorrow. I have time ſtill to make my claim. How ſhall I act?—Shall I never leave this hotel?—Has the builder been here?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I can get nothing done. My whole life long I have been diſtracted with the multiplicity of my affairs.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: And ſo I am afraid, my lord, you always will be.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why ſo, ſir?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Becauſe your lordſhip undertakes ſo much, and does ſo little.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: So he has not been here?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Nor the lawyers?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Nor my ſteward?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Nor Sir George?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Where is Lady Vibrate? Where is Lady Jane? Are they all in their graves? Have none of them ſhewn ſigns of life yet?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Not one. Your lordſhip is the only perſon in the family who begin your miſeries ſo ſoon in a morning.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The croſſes and cares that prey upon me are enough to make any man on earth miſerable.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord, but if you would care leſs both yourſelf and your ſervants would ſleep the more. My lady cares for nothing; and ſhe can ſleep, when ſhe is in bed, and ſing and dance and laugh at your lordſhip's cares and fears, when ſhe is up.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: She will drive me mad!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: (Going.) Ah! Here ſhe is, as it were for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Tell Harry to admit the Doctor—No. Not juſt yet. Yes. In five minutes. I don't know when. [Exit Thompſon.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Upon my honor, my lord, you are the moſt inſupportable perſon imaginable. You vociferate worſe than the man who calls when my carriage ſtops the way. Is any body dying? Is the houſe on fire? Is the world at an end?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: By the life your ladyſhip leads, I ſhould ſuppoſe it is pretty near.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You always give me ſuch ſhocking head-achs of a morning.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You always give me ſuch ſhocking heart-achs of an evening.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Did not I ſend to you laſt night, to requeſt your lordſhip would not diſturb me?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: It has been your ladyſhip's amuſement to diſturb me all your life.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Your lordſhip knows I love amuſement.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I have not ſlept a wink ſince.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You had ſlept quite enough before. Pray how long are we to remain in this hotel? Your lordſhip ſhould remember, it is degrading for a man of rank to doze away life, in the ſtile of a colonel reduced to half pay.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip ſhould remember, it is degrading for a woman of rank to riot away life, and reduce her creditors to live without pay.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Pſhaw! That is the old ſtory.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: But it is a very true ſtory. It is a great misfortune that perſons ſo oppoſite ſhould pair.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
A terrible one indeed. I am all gaiety and good humour: you are all turmoil and lamentation. I ſing, laugh, and welcome pleaſure
wherever I find it: you take your lantern to look for miſery, which the ſun itſelf cannot diſcover.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I am overwhelmed by croſſes and vexations; and you participate in none of them.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No. Heaven be praiſed!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Will you attend to me, my lady, for half an hour?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Mercy! Attend to you for half an hour! You, my lord, may think proper to be as miſerable as Job: but I am not Job's wife.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I inſiſt, Lady Vibrate, on a ſerious anſwer. How ought I to act? What ſhould I do, in this law affair?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I cannot tell what you ought to do: but I know what you will do.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Do you? What?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The recovery of this property would enable me to give my daughter a portion ſuitable to her rank. If it is loſt, ſhe will be almoſt deſtitute of fortune.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You ſhould have thought of that before, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Before? Why I have thought of nothing elſe for years. I have aſked every body's advice.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And followed nobody's.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: It ſhall be ſo. The ejectment ſhall be ſerved: proceedings ſhall commence.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I ſay, they ſhall. I am determined.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I know you, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You know! I ſay they ſhall, if it be only to prove that you know nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! A pleaſant motive! But even that will not be ſtrong enough.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: But it will, my lady.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But it won't, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I ſay it will, my lady.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I ſay it won't, my lord.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Coot morgen, to my coot lordt und my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, Doctor, ſtop my lady's tongue.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, Doctor, give my lord a quieting draught.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I ſhall do efery ting as vat you deſire, my coot lordt und my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Can nothing ſilence you, Lady Vibrate? Shall I never have a quiet hearing? I want to talk with you and the Doctor on a thouſand things.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Yes; you wiſh to have all the talk to yourſelf.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: On the marriage of our daughter.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Oh, with all my heart. A marriage at leaſt begins with muſic, feaſting, and dancing, So ſay on.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I am not yet determined in favor of Sir George.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But I am. (While they ſpeak, the Doctor geſticulates in favor of each.)

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr Delaval is an unobjectionable gentleman; and he was the firſt ſuitor.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sir George can ſing; Sir George can dance; Sir George has air, grace, faſhion, and fortune.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Pſhaw! His beſt qualities are prudence, and attention to his own concerns. Aſk the Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He has fery moſh prudence, my coot lordt.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha! I vow, Sir George is the moſt airy, thoughtleſs, pleaſant perſon living: except myſelf.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya; Sair Shorge is fery moſh pleaſant: und my latyſhip is fery moſh more pleaſant.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Abſurd. His humour is calm, cold, and ſerious.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Fery ſerious, inteet.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Whimſical, animated, delightful.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Fery animate, fery telightful, upon my vordt.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I never met a more diſcreet ſenſible man in my life.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: True: for he thinks of nothing but his pleaſures.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: His affairs, you mean.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I tell you, my lord, he is exactly what I wiſh: the very ſoul of levity, whim, and laughter.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I tell you, my lady, he is exactly like myſelf: prudent, and full of ſage heſitation. He conſiders before he acts. Does he not, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yuſt as vat you ſay, my coot lordt.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: He never conſiders at all. Does he, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yuſt as vat you ſay, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: How ſo? We cannot both be right.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
You ſhall pleaſe to make me parton, my coot lordt. Sair Shorge vas all as vat you ſay;
und all as vat my coot laty ſay. Mit my laty, he vas merry: mit my lordt, he vas ſad. Mit my laty, he vas laugh, und vas ſing, und vas tance: und he vas make melancholy, und miſery, und vas do all dat ſhall make agréable mit my lordt.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is he ſo variable?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, he vas fery moſh comply: fery moſh coot humeur. He vas alvay make agréable. Bote vas my lordtſhip und my latyſhip know dat Mr. Delafal vas com from Italy?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Come where? To England?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He vas in de houſe below. I vas ſee und ſpeak mit his falet.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: In this hotel?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He vas yuſt arrife, und vas demandt dat he ſhall ſee my lordtſhip; oder my latyſhip.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I am very ſorry he is here. He is a dun of the moſt diſagreeable kind, and ſhall not ſee me; and I hope, my lord, you will no longer permit his addreſſes to Lady Jane. My word is given to Sir George. Come with me, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord, if I intrude with too little ceremony. Something I hope will be allowed to a mind much diſturbed, and a heart deeply wounded and impatient to eaſe its pangs.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Which way deeply wounded, Mr. Delaval?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Can your lordſhip aſk? Was it not with your permiſſion I paid my addreſſes to Lady Jane? And was the ardour of my affection or the extent of my hopes unknown?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why, I did permit, and I did not. I had my doubts.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: My viſits were daily, their purpoſe was declared, and I ſhould imagine I ſpoke more reſpectfully to ſay that you permitted than that you connived at them.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: True: but ſtill I had my doubts.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Thoſe doubts have ſtung me to the ſoul; and I could wiſh you had expreſſed them more decidedly.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Impoſſible! Doubts here, doubts there, doubts every where. No rational man can be decided, on any point whatever. My doubts are my continual plagues: my whole life is conſumed by them,

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: It appears, my lord, you have conquered them on one ſubject.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay indeed! I wiſh to heaven I had! What ſubject is that?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You have affianced your daughter to Sir George Verſatile.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Humph!—Yes; and no. I have; and I have not. I cannot determine. Sir George is a prudent man, his eſtate is large, and the Verſatiles are an ancient race. But your family is ancient, you are prudent, and the wealth left by your uncle is at leaſt equal. What can I ſay? What can I do? I don't know which to take nor which to refuſe. I am everlaſtingly in theſe difficulties. I am haraſſed night and day by them: they are the night mare, they ſit upon my boſom, oppreſs me, ſuffocate me. I cannot act. I cannot move.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
This, my lord, may be an apology to yourſelf, but the conſequence to me is miſery. Your daughter lived in my heart: with her I had promiſed
myſelf ages of happineſs; and had cheriſhed a paſſion, impatient perhaps, but, ardent and pure as her own thoughts. This paſſion your conduct authorized. My fortune, my life, my ſoul, were devoted to her. Mine was no light or wanton dalliance; nor did I expect a light and wanton conduct from the noble family of which your lordſhip is the head.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What do you mean, Mr. Delaval? I told you I was undecided; and ſo I am ſtill. My lady, you know, was never much your friend. Sir George is her favourite.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: And is Lady Jane equally changeable?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I don't know. She is my daughter; and, judging by myſelf, I ſhould ſuppoſe ſhe is perplexed, and doubtful. She never, I believe, declared in your favour?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Not expreſsly, my lord. She referred me to time and you. 'Tis true I flattered myſelf her affections were wholly mine. Should ſhe prefer Sir George, or any other man, be my feelings what they will, I then am ſilenced. My heart could not be ſatisfied with cold compliance. Oh no! 'Tis of a different ſtamp. I am told ſhe is not at home. I hope however ſhe will not have the cruelty to deny me a laſt interview: till when I take my leave. Only ſuffer me to remark that, had you diſcovered in me any ſecret vice, any defects dangerous to the happineſs of the woman I adore, you then were juſtified in your preſent conduct. But, if you have no ſuch accuſation to prefer, I muſt do my feelings the violence to declare I cannot but think it highly unworthy of a man of honor. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval—Inſolent!—Highly unworthy of a man of honor?—I will challenge him.—He ſhall find whether I am a man of honor, or no. I will challenge him. Harry!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Run. Tell that Mr. Delaval—Hold—Yes, fly! Tell him—Stay. Get me pen ink and paper—I will teach him to inſult—No. I will not do him the honor to write. Order him back.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Order who, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He ſhall give me ſatisfaction. In that at leaſt I am determined. He ſhall give—And yet what is ſatisfaction? Is it to be run through the body? Shot through the head? A man may then indeed be ſaid to be ſatisfied—I had forgotten my doubts on duelling—Tell my lady I wiſh to ſpeak to her. No—

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: She is here, my lord. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE XI. Enter LADY VIBRATE and the DOCTOR.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: What is the matter, my lord? You ſeem to be even in a worſe humour than uſual!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval has treated me diſreſpectfully!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Have not I a thouſand times told you he is a diſagreeable impertinent perſon?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why, God forgive me, but I really find myſelf of your ladyſhip's opinion! 'Tis a thing I believe that never happened before!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
And a thing I believe that will never
happen again! I hope, my lord, you are now determined in favor of Sir George?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Poſitively. Finally. I pledge my honor.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You hear, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my coot laty; I vas hear.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I ſay, I pledge my honor. I authoriſe you, my lady, to deliver that meſſage to the baronet: and, that I may not have time to begin to doubt, I will inſtantly be gone. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: This is fortunate!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, fery moſh fortunate! fery moſh!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Had Mr. Delaval married my daughter, we ſhould have had a continual ſermon on reaſon, common ſenſe, and good order! And theſe and ſuch like antediluvian notions muſt have been introduced to our family.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah, dat ſhall be pad! fery pad inteet, my coot laty!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Now that Sir George is the man, the danger is over.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is creat pleſſing!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But what think you are my daughter's thoughts? I fear ſhe has a kind of eſteem for Delaval. He was her firſt lover.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya; ſhe vas fery moſh eſteem Mr. Delafal, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But I obſerve ſhe liſtens with great pleaſure to the gay prattle of Sir George.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh! fery creat inteet, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: We muſt ſecond the riſing paſſion: for we muſt get rid of that ſolemn ſir.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yuſt as vat you ſay, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Go to her, Doctor; convince her how intolerable it will be to have a huſband whom ſhe cannot quarrel with, nor reproach. Paint in the moſt lively colours the ſtupid life ſhe muſt lead, with ſo reaſonable a man.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I ſhall do efery ting as vat ſhall make agréable, my coot laty. Dat is my vay. My laty, I vas your moſh obliſhe fery omple ſairfant, my laty. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. The hall of the hotel. WILLIAMS and HARRY. LUCY ſpeaking to the maſter of the hotel.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: ALL you ſay is very true, Mr. Harry. Our maſters ſuppoſe we have neither ſenſe nor feeling; yet exact every thing that requires the five ſenſes in perfection. They expect we ſhould know their meaning before they open their lips; yet won't allow we have common underſtanding.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: More ſhame for 'em. I warrant for all that we can game, run in debt, get in drink, and be as proud and domineering as they for their lives.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, yes: let them but change places and they would ſoon find we could riſe to their vices, and they could ſink to ours, with all the eaſe imaginable.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: They have no ſuch notion though, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: That is their vanity, Mr. Harry. I have lived with Mr. Delaval ever ſince he returned from India; and, though he is a good— (Sees Lucy) Hay! Surely—It muſt be her! Do you know that young woman, Mr. Harry?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: No: but I have heard a ſtrange ſtory about her.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Ay!—It is!—What?—I am ſure it is Lucy!—What ſtrange ſtory have you heard?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Why that ſhe came here late laſt night with a young gentleman, now above, pretending to be his waiting maid.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: With a gentleman!— (Aſide) Oh the jilt! Waiting maid to a man? I never heard of ſuch a thing!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Nor any body elſe.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aſide) The deceitful huſſey!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: (Hears a bell) That's my lord's bell. I told you, he is never eaſy. I muſt go.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aſide) I am glad of it—By all means, Mr. Harry. Good-day— [Exit Harry.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Run away with a gentleman! Oh!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Coming forward) I declare, there is Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aſide) What a fool was I to believe ſhe loved me!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aſide) How my heart beats! Dear, dear! I could wiſh to ſpeak to him—but then if any harm ſhould come of it?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aſide) She ſhall not eſcape me!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aſide) I ſhould like to aſk him how he does—But I muſt not betray my dear lady. (Going)

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Placing himſelf in her way) I beg pardon, ma'am.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aſide) Does not he know me?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I thought I had ſeen you before; but I find I am miſtaken!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aſide) What does he mean?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: You are very like a young woman I once knew.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aſide) How angry he looks!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: But ſhe was a modeſt pretty behaved perſon; and not an arrant jilt.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Who is a jilt, Mr. Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: One Lucy Langford, that I courted and promiſed to marry: but I know better, now.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: You do, Mr. Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I do, madam.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: It is very well, Mr. Williams! It is very well! Pray let me go about my buſineſs!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Oh, to be ſure! I have no right to ſtop you.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: You have no right to ſpeak to me as you do, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: No, no; ha, ha, ha! I dare ſay, I have not.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Her paſſions riſing) No, you have not; and ſo I beg you will let me paſs. My miſtreſs—I mean—

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Ay, ay! You mean, your maſter.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Do I, ſir? Well! Since you pleaſe to think ſo—ſo be it.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: All the ſervants know it is a man! Would you deny it?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p:
I deny nothing, Mr. Williams; and, if
you are minded to make this an excuſe for being as treacherous as the reſt of your ſex, (Keeping down her ſobs) you are very welcome, Mr. Williams—I ſhall neither die—nor cry, at parting.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I dare ſay not. The young gentleman above ſtairs will comfort you.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Burſts into tears) It is a baſe falſe ſtory. I have no young gentleman above ſtairs, nor below ſtairs neither, to comfort me! and you ought to know me better.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Did you or did you not come here late laſt night?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: With a young gentleman?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: No. Yes. Don't aſk me ſuch queſtions.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: No! You are aſhamed to anſwer them.

div.head: SCENE III. MARIA from the ſtaircaſe.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Calls) Lucy!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Ma'am! Sir! Coming, ſir!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: There! There! I will ſee what ſort of a ſpark it is, however.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Struggling) Be quiet, then! Keep away! You ſhan't!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Deſcending) What is the matter? Who is moleſting you?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (To Maria) Go back, ſir! Go back!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I will ſee, I am determined!

div.head: SCENE IV. DELAVAL from a room door.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Williams!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I tell you, I will. (Looking at Maria) Hay! Bleſs me!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Why, Lucy! Mr. Williams!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: My young lady, as I live!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Why do not you anſwer, Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Coming, ſir!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Mercy! It is my brother's voice! What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Hide your face with your handkerchief, ma'am. Pull down your hat.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Pray do not betray me, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: If you do, I will never ſpeak to you as long as I have breath to draw.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: How betray?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Don't ſay you know us. Mind! Not for the world!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Maria and Lucy up the ſtaircaſe.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: What is it you are about, Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Nothing, ſir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: What do you mean by nothing? Whom were you wrangling with?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Me, ſir? Wrangling, ſir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Why are you ſo confuſed?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why, ſir, I—I committed a ſmall miſtake. I was aſking—aſking after a gentleman that that that proved not to be a gentleman—that is—not not the gentleman that I ſuppoſed.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Why did you not come back with your meſſage?—Have you learnt the addreſs of Sir George?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, ſir: he lives in Upper Groſvenorſtreet; his name on the door.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
Well, be in the way.—The day ſhall not paſs before I ſee him. My own wrongs I could forgive. He it ſeems is preferred; and perhaps
I have no right to complain: But for his injuries to my ſiſter he ſhall render me a dear account.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: What can be the reaſon of Miſs Delaval's diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Peeping from the top of the ſtairs) Hſt! Hſt! Mr. Williams!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Is it you?—Oh! now I ſhall know.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: LADY VIBRATE and LADY JANE.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Really, daughter, I cannot underſtand you.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No wonder, madam; for I do not half underſtand myſelf.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Is it poſſible you can heſitate? The good humour and complaiſance of Sir George might captivate any woman.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: They are very engaging: but they are dangerous.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: His character is too pliant. If others are merry, ſo is he: if they are ſad, he is the ſame. Their joys and ſorrows play upon his countenance: but, though they may ſlightly graze, they do not penetrate his heart. Even while he relieves, he ſcarcely feels them.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Pſhaw! He is a delightful man.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I grant he does his utmoſt. But it is a folly to be the ſlave even of an endeavour to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! Upon my honor, you are a whimſical young lady! Afraid of marrying
a man becauſe of his aſſiduous endeavours to pleaſe! As if that were a huſband's failing! You can prefer no ſuch accuſation againſt Mr. Delaval.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I own he is of a very different character. Firm and inflexible, he imagines he makes virtue his rule, and reaſon his guide.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Firm indeed? No, no: ferocious, obſtinate, perverſe. Sir George tries to be agreeable, and is ſucceſsful: Mr. Delaval has no fear of offending, and does not miſs his aim.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Heaven help us! We all have faults and follies enough.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval never was approved by me; and this morning he has inſulted your father.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Inſulted! How do you mean, madam? Mr. Delaval is abroad! Has he written?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No. He is here.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Here! And has he not thought proper to let me know of his arrival?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No, no. The haughty gentleman has only thought proper to reproach Lord Vibrate for admitting the pretenſions of Sir George. He is too proud to endure a competitor.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Indeed! Such pride is the very way to inſure his competitor ſucceſs. Inſulted my father!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I will leave you to judge how deeply when I tell you that, fluctuating and undecided as Lord Vibrate always is, he was ſo offended that he pledged his honor in favor of Sir George.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Inſult my father, and not deign to let me know of his arrival!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I hope, when Sir George comes, you will admit him.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Certainly, madam; certainly.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And that Mr. Delaval will be denied.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: It ſeems I need give myſelf no concern about that: the gentleman will not even take the trouble to ſend up his name.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I am glad you feel it properly.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Pardon me, madam. I will not condeſcend to feel it, in the leaſt. It ſhall not affect me; no not for a moment. I had indeed conceived a very different opinion of Mr. Delaval. I am glad I have diſcovered my error, before it is too late. I could not have believed it poſſible! But it ſhall not diſturb me. It ſhall give me no uneaſineſs. I will keep myſelf perfectly cool, and unconcerned, and—ungenerous, unfeeling man!

div.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: She is delightfully piqued, and Sir George will ſucceed!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Without) Are the ladies above?

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: (Without) Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I hear him! The very ſound of his voice inſpires mirth.

div.stage: Enter SIR GEORGE.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Lady!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I am infinitely glad to ſee you, Sir George! You are come at a lucky moment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is then my fate decided?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: It is! It is!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Happy tidings!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But firſt tell me—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Any thing! Every thing! Speak!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Are you not of my opinion?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To be ſure I am! What is it?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: That pleaſure is the buſineſs of life.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, beyond all doubt!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: That inſpecting accounts—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is vulgar drudgery!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And looking after our affairs—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A vile loſs of time!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: That care in the face denotes—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The owner a fool!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And that ſorrow is a very ridiculous thing!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Fit only to excite laughter!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Why then, Sir George, I am your friend.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ten thouſand thouſand thanks! But, what ſays my lord?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Would you believe it? He conſents, has pledged his honor, and ſent the meſſage by me.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Rapture! Enchantment!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Yes. The reign of pleaſure is about to begin!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Light, free, and fantaſtic; dancing an eternal round!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No domeſtic troubles!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No grave looks!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No ſerious thoughts!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: We will never think at all!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No cares, no frowns!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: None, none, by heavens, none! It ſhall be ſpring and ſunſhine all the year!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Then our appearance in public!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Splendid! Dazzling!—Driving to the opera!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Dreſſing for Ranelagh!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A phaeton to-day!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: A curricle to-morrow!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Daſh over the downs of Piccadilly, deſcend the heights of St. James's, make the tour of Pall-mall, coaſt Whitehall—

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Back again to Bond-ſtreet—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Scour the ſquares, thunder at the doors!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: How do you do? How do you do? How do you do?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And away we rattle, till ſtone walls are but gliding ſhadows, and the whole world a Galanty ſhow.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You are a charming man, Sir George! and Lady Jane is yours.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My dear lady, your words inſpire me! I am all air, ſpirit, ſoul! I tread the milky way, and ſtep upon the ſtars!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But you muſt not, before the marriage, talk thus to Lord Vibrate. Silly man! He and you will never agree.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh yes, but we ſhall. I—I—I like his humour!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Do you?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Prodigiouſly! Whenever I am in his company, I am as grave as Good Friday.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He is full of ſage reflection. So am I. Doubtful of every thing. So am I. Anxious for the preſent, provident for the future. So am I. Overflowing with prudential maxims; ſententious, ſentimental, and ſolemn. So am I.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You ſentimental!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: As grace before meat, in the mouth of an alderman.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You ſolemn!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: As the black patch on a judge's wig.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I muſt tell you, Sir George, I hate ſentiment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! So do I!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Solemnity is all a farce.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And thoſe that act it buffoons. I know it!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I love mirth, pleaſantry—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Humour, whim, wit, feaſting, revelry, ſhout, ſong, dance, and joke. So do I! So do I! So do I!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: The very mention of duties and cares makes me ſplenetic.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Curſe catch duties! I hate them! Give me life, the wide world, the fair ſun, and the free air!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I ſay, give me midnight, the rattling of chariot wheels, and the lighted flambeau!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay! A rout! A craſh of coaches! A lane of footmen! A blazing ſtair-caſe! A ſqueeze through the anti-chamber! Card tables! Wax lights! Patent lamps! Bath ſtoves and ſuffocation! Oh lord! Oh lord!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Exquiſite! You are a delightful man!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Am I?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You enter perfectly into all my ideas!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Do I?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And deſcribe them even better than I myſelf can.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, my dear lady!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Yes, you do.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
But then, ha, ha, ha! That you
ſhould be able to fall in with my lord's abſurdities 〈…〉 !

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nothing more eaſy. I have one infallible rule to pleaſe all tempers. I learnt it of our friend the Doctor.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sure! What is that?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I prove that every body is always in the right.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Prove my huſband to be in the right! Do if you can.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My lord loves to be reſtleſs, and doubtful, and diſtreſſed: he delights in teaſing and tormenting himſelf; and why ſhould I interrupt his pleaſures?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Very true.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I fail in with his humour. I ſhew him how rational it is, afford him new arguments for diſcontent, and encourage him to be miſerable.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh you malicious divle!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My dear lady, you miſtake. I do it from pure compaſſion. It makes him happy. Every child delights in the ſqueaking of its own trumpet; and ſhall I have the cruelty to break the toy? A well bred perſon is cautious never to contradict. It is become a very eſſential requiſite to ſay Ay, and No, in the moſt complying manner poſſible.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ah, Sir George, you are one of the dear inimitable few.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Only a copy of your charming ſelf.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You and I muſt totally reform our ſtupid family. Amuſement ſhall be our perpetual occupation.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Day and night.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: We will commence with your marriage. It ſhall be ſplendid!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A feaſt, a concert, a ball! The whole town ſhall ring with it!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I hate a private wedding. A ſmall ſelect party is my averſion.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, nothing is ſo inſipid! Pleaſure cannot be calm.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I wiſh to be ſeen, and heard—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And talked of, and paragraphed, and praiſed, and blamed, and admired, and envied, and laughed at, and imitated!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I live but in a crowd.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Give me hurry, noiſe, embarraſſment—

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Confuſion, diſorder—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Tumult, tempeſt, uproar, elbowing, ſqueezing, preſſing, puſhing, ſqueaking, ſqualling, fainting!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Exquiſite! Tranſporting!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You remember I receive maſks this evening?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Can I forget?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You will be there?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: There? Ay! Though I ſhould come in my coffin.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! An excellent idea! I never yet ſaw a maſk in the character of a Memento mori.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ah! Turn about, and you will ſee a Memento mori without a maſk!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: (Without) I cannot tell. I will conſider, and ſend an anſwer.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
Here he comes, to interrupt our delightful dreams: a very antidote to mirth and
pleaſure. He will give you a full doſe of the diſmals. But you muſt ſtay and ſpeak to him. Remember, his honor is pledged: inſiſt upon that. I pity but cannot relieve you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I have been too ſudden. I ought not to have pledged my honor. This is the conſequence of haſty determination: of not doubting before we decide. Shall I never correct myſelf of that fault? (Sees Sir George. They look full at each other till Sir George catches the ſame diſmal kind of countenance) Ah, Sir George! Here am I, brim full of anxiety and turmoil!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Alas! Man was born to trouble.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Perplexed on every ſide; thwarted in every plan: no domeſtic comfort, no friend to grieve with me, no creature to ſhare my miſeries.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Melancholy caſe!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: One croſſing me, another blaming me, and my wife driving me mad!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Diſtreſſing ſituation!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: My cares laughed at, my vigilance mocked, my ſufferings inſulted! And why? Becauſe I am cautious! becauſe I doubt! becauſe I am provident! What is man without money?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A fountain without water.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: A clock without a dial.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Warming and becoming rapid as he proceeds) What is it that buys reſpect, and honor, and power, and privilege, and houſes, and lands, and wit, and beauty, and learning, and lords, and commons, and—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why money!—Then the manners of this diſſipated age!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: They are truly ſhocking! They, they, they are abſurd, ridiculous, odious, abominable.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: And to what do they lead?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To every thing that is horrid! To loſs of peace, loſs of property, loſs of principle, loſs of reſpect, bankruptcy, ruin, contempt, diſeaſe, and death!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: (Aſide) Yes, yes: he's the man! I do not think I repent—Heaven be praiſed, Sir George, you are a man of underſtanding; an economiſt. You will regulate your family and affairs to my heart's content.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! it ſhall be my ſtudy! my daily practice! my duty! my delight!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You make me happy—and yet I cannot but wonder, being ſo rational a man, how you and my lady ſhould agree ſo well.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Dear, my lord, why ſo? Women are the moſt manageable good creatures upon earth.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Women good?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Indubitably: when they are pleaſed.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: So they ſay is the devil.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The ſweet angels deſerve to be humoured. Their ſmiles are ſo enchanting! And, ſhould they frown, who can be angry when we know the dear wayward ſyrens will only look the more bewitching, as ſoon as they are out of their pouts? It is ſo delightful to ſee the Sun breaking from behind a cloud.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Pſhaw! When a woman begins to grow old—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Huſh! The Sun—The Sun never
grows old. I grant you that formerly there uſed to be old women: but there are none now!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then you think me a fool for being wretched at my wife's thoughtleſſneſs, caprice, and impertinence?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, I don't. Every body tells us that wives were born to be the plague of their huſbands.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: And mine is the greateſt of plagues!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What is a wife's duty? To obey her lord and maſter. 'Tis her marriage promiſe, and the law binds her to it. She is the miniſter of his pleaſures, the handmaid of his wants, his goods, his chattels, his vendible property.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay: we find the huſband may take the wife to market in a halter.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: In which I ſhould hope he would afterward hang himſelf!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: My lady thinks of nothing but revelling, and racketing, and turning the world upſide down!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis a great pity.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Her tongue is my torment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The perpetual motion! It never ceaſes!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then how can you like her company?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: She is not my wife.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No, or you would not be ſuch good friends. Did ſhe ſay any thing concerning the marriage?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, yes. She delivered your lordſhip's kind meſſage.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, that I had pledged my honor?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Irrevocably.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I was very raſh. Haſty reſolutions bring long repentance—She inſiſts that the nuptials ſhall be public!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Does ſhe, indeed?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: For my part, I hate any diſplay of vanity.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It is extremely ridiculous! What would our oſtentation, pomp, and magnificence be, but advertiſing ourſelves to the world as fools and coxcombs?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is that a rational uſe of money?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Should it not be applied to relieve the aged, comfort the poor, ſuccour the diſtreſſed—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Reward merit, encourage induſtry, and promote the public good?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Promote a farce!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Very true: the public good is a farce!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The true uſe of money is to defend our rights—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Revenge our wrongs, purchaſe for the preſent, provide for the future, ſecure power, buy friends, bid defiance to enemies, and lead the world in a ſtring!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay! Now you talk ſenſe. So, if I ſhould conſent, the wedding ſhall be private.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Calm: tranquil.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No feaſting.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No dancing: no muſic: no pantomime pleaſures: but all ſilent, ſerene, pure, and undiſturbed.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: We will juſt invite a ſelect party.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A choſen few.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: None but our real and ſincere friends.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And then we ſhall be ſure the houſe will hold them.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: My lord, the builder deſires to know if you will ſee him?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I. am coming. I will be with him in five minutes.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: He ſays, he can ſtay no longer.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then let him go. I will be with him preſently.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: The lawyers have ſent word they are waiting for your lordſhip, at Counſellor Demur's chambers.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Very well. There let them wait. The law is ſlow, and every man ought to be ſlow who is going to law. Come with me, Sir George. I have ſome papers to conſult you upon.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: The tradeſpeople too are below.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Thus it is! I am eternally beſieged! I never have a moment to myſelf!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: This is the tenth time they have been here, by your lordſhip's own appointment.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: They are become quite ſurly. They all abuſe me; and ſome of them don't ſpare your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Do you hear, Sir George?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh ſhocking! Your tradeſpeople are a ſad unreaſonable ſet. You cannot convince them that, if we were to keep our appointments, be punctual in our payments, and know what we do want and what we do not, we ſhould no longer be perſons of faſhion.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p:
I am juſt come from the lawyers, my lord. The courts are ſitting, their clients waiting,
and, if your lordſhip do not go immediately, they will be gone.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Very true; and this laſt opportunity of ſerving an ejectment will be loſt. I have a thouſand things to attend to. Would you be kind enough, Sir George, to go and—Hold—No—I don't know what to do! The eſtate is valuable: but law is damnable. I may loſe the cauſe: it may coſt even more than it is worth. Writs of error! Brought into chancery! Carried up to the Lords!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Then the ſtupidity of juries, the fictions of law, the chicanery of lawyers, their tricking, twiſting, turning, lying, wrangling, browbeating, cajoling!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Their frauds, colluſions, perjuries, robberies!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay! Detinue, replevin, plea, imparlance, replication, rejoinder, rebutter, ſurrejoinder, ſurrebutter, demurrer—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Take breath! We ought both to demur: for it is the devil's dance, and both Plaintiff and Defendant are obliged to pay the piper.

div.head: SCENE I. The apartments of LORD VIBRATE.
div.stage: LADY JANE, her WOMAN, the DOCTOR, and FOOTMAN.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: TELL the young gentleman I wait his pleaſure. (Exit Footman.) It is very ſingular! Men, I believe, do not often travel attended by waiting maids!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is de myſtery, my Laty Shane.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What can he want to ſay to me?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is de more myſtery, my Laty Shane. He vas fery moſh young, und fery moſh handſome, und he vas fery moſh make fall in lofe mit you, my Laty Shane.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Laty Shane vas ſo full of de beauty dat you vas make ſharm efery pody, my Laty Shane! Und as your name vas make mention, my Laty Shane, he vas all ſo pale as deaths!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aſide to her woman.) You are ſure, you ſay, Mr. Delaval made enquiries; and ſent up his name?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane.) Law, my lady! Could you think he would not? I ſaw him before ten o'clock; juſt as you ſent me where I was kept ſo long: and, goodneſs! Had you beheld what a taking he was in! I warrant you, my lady, he aſked a hundred and a hundred queſtions in a breath; and all about you!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Well, go now where I deſired you.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Yes, my lady. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. Footman returns introducing MARIA. Salute.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide) Why do I tremble thus?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (To Doctor) What a charming countenance!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, fery moſh ſharming!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: How prepoſſeſſing his appearance!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya: he vas fery moſh poſſeſs.

div.stage: Re-enter Footman.

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: Sir George has ſent this domino and maſk, to know if they meet your ladyſhip's approbation.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Italian refinement, copied after ſome Venetian Ciciſbeo. Put them down.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide. Regarding the domino and maſk.) Here his preſents, and here his affections are now directed! How ſhall I ſupport the ſcene?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: You wiſh, ſir, to ſpeak to me.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Faltering) Embarraſſed by the—liberty—I have taken—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Let me requeſt you to wave all apology, and tell me which way I can oblige or ſerve you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: You are acquainted with Sir George—I—you—Pray pardon me. I am overcome. My ſpirits are—ſo agitated—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
