sp.p: (Eagerly reaching a chair.) Sit down, ſir. You are unwell! Bleſs me! Doctor!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane ſignificantly.) I vas tell my Laty Shane vat it vas—Here, ſair, you ſhmell mit dat elixir; und I ſhall make your neck bandt tie looſe, und— (Going to looſen her neckcloth.)

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Alarmed and putting him away.) Pray forbear!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (Aſide. Imitating the heaving of the boſom.) Ah ha! Der Teufel! He vas a vomans!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Are you better?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: A moment's air. (Goes to the window.)

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (Aſide) Dat vas de ſometing myſtery!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane.) If you would indulge me a few minutes in private?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: By all means—Doctor— (Whiſpers.)

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ya, my Laty Shane, I vas unterſtandt; und I vas do efery ting as vat ſhall make agréable. Dat is my vay—Sair, I vas your moſh obliſhe fery omple ſairfant, ſair. I vas unterſtandt. My Laty Shane, I vas your moſh obliſhe fery omple ſairfant, my Laty Shane— (Aſide) Ah ha! [Exit.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Take courage, ſir.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am unequal to the taſk. This diſguiſe ſits ill upon me.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am not what I ſeem. I—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am a woman.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Diſtreſſed—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: By poverty?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh no. I come to claim your counſel.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: To prevent miſchief. The ſhedding of blood.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: The ſhedding of blood?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Without.) I will be with you again preſently, my lady.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p:
Mercy! It is Sir George! What ſhall I do? He muſt not ſee me! This way— (Hurries on the domino and maſk.) Aid me, dear lady, to
conceal myſelf; and excuſe conduct which I cannot now explain.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Depend upon me, madam. (Aſide) This is as unaccountable as it is alarming!

div.head: SCENE IV. MARIA in the back ground. SIR GEORGE introduced by a Footman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I come, my charming Lady Jane, flying and full of buſineſs, to conſult you on a thouſand important affairs!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Surely! What are they?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I don't know!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Heyday!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: They have every one ſlipped my memory.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Miraculous!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Whenever I have the inexpreſſible pleaſure of enjoying your ſmiles, I can think of nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide) Perjured man!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: My ſmiles! Ha, ha, ha! What if I ſhould happen to frown?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Impoſſible! No lowering clouds of diſcontent dare ever ſhade the heavenly brightneſs of your brow.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Very prettily ſaid, upon my word. Where did you learn it?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: From you! 'Tis pure inſpiration, and you are my muſe.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No, no; 'tis a flight beyond me. I love plain proſe.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
So do I! A mere common place matter of fact man▪ I! The weather, the time of the
day, the hiſtory of where I dined laſt, the names and titles of the company, the diſhes brought to table, the health, ſickneſs, deaths, births and marriages of my acquaintance, and ſuch like toothpick topics for me! I am as literal in my narratives as any town-crier; and repeat them as often.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Yet I ſhould wiſh to talk a little common ſenſe.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! So ſhould I! I aſſure you, I am for pros and cons and whys and wherefores. Your Ariſtotles, and Platos, and Senecas, and Catos are my delight! I honor their precepts, venerate their cogitations, and adore the length of their beards! which luckily reminds me of the maſquerade. Is my domino to your taſte?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Ancient ſages, dominos, and taſte.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Did you not notice the colour?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Oh! The taſte of a domino is in its colour?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why, no: but there may be meaning.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mine is ſaffron.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Cruel queſtion! Hymen and his robe.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Oh oh!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide) She is pleaſed with his perfidy.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: A very ſignificant riddle truly!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Advancing) Are you ſo ſoon to be married, ſir?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Lady Jane! What frolickſome gentleman is this? In maſquerade ſo early, and my domino!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Permit me once more to aſk, if you are ſoon to be married?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Your queſtion, ſir, is improperly addreſſed. Put it, if you pleaſe, to that lady.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide to Sir George) Is that the lady to whom the queſtion ought to be put?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) What does he mean?—Will you indulge me, ſir, by taking off that maſk?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis mine; and I am induced to claim it, from the great curioſity I have to ſee your face.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Do you not adore this lady?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) An odd queſtion!—More than language can expreſs!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh, falſehood!—Then I put myſelf under her protection.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You know guardian angels when you ſee them. Pray, however, let us become acquainted.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: For what reaſon?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Twould gratify me. I ſhould like you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I certainly ſhould. There is ſomething of pathos and muſic in your voice, which, which—I never heard but one to equal it.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And whoſe voice was that?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, that—that was a voice ſo ingenuous, ſo affectionate, ſo faſcinating!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But whoſe voice was it?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aſide) What does this mean?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Tell me, and you ſhall ſee my face.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aſide) Aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I muſt not—I dare not—I ſhall never hear it more!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aſide) My feelings ſo overpower me I ſhall betray myſelf. (To Lady Jane) Permit me to retire.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: You have alarmed and ſtrangely moved me! I hope you will return?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh yes; and moſt happy to have your permiſſion.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why do they whiſper? (To Maria going) Will you not let me know who you are?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Becauſe—I am one you do not love.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: One I do not love!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aſide) This is incomprehenſible!

div.stage: Re-enter MARIA haſtily.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane) Oh, madam!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What more is the matter?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: For your life, do not mention the names of either of theſe gentlemen to the other!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What gentlemen?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: He is coming! They do not perſonally know each other. If they ſhould, there would be murder! I dare not ſtay. For the love of God beware! [Exit maſked as Delaval enters.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Calling) Harkye, ſir, come back! My domino! I ſhall want it in an hour or ſo—Who have we here?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (With much agitation of manner) Your ladyſhip's very humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p:
Oh! How do you do? How do you do? (Aſide) Who can that lady be? She knows them both, it ſeems; and knows their rivalſhip!
Her terror is contagious! Is their hatred ſo deadly? I ſhall certainly betray them to each other.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) What a ſtrange behaviour ſhe puts on! Does ſhe affect to overlook me? (Obſerving Sir George) Who is this?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Are you juſt arrived?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: This very morning: ſooner I fear than—than—was deſired.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Do you think ſo? (To Sir George) Why don't you go to Lady Vibrate? She is waiting.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis the fate of forty.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To wait. (Aſide. Eyeing Delaval) Who can this ſpark be, that ſhe wants me gone?—Pray what is the name of the youth that has made ſo free with my domino and maſk?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I really don't know.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Don't know?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I can't anſwer queſtions at preſent. I am flurried; out of humour.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I fear at my intruſion?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I wiſh you had come at another time.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I expected my viſit would be unwelcome: let me requeſt, however, to ſay a few words.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Well, well; another time, I tell you: when I am alone.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh ho!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: They were meant for your private ear.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) Were they ſo?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) By her confuſion and his manner, I ſuſpect this to be the baſe betrayer of my ſiſter's peace: the man whoſe bare image makes my heart ſicken, and my blood recoil.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aſide) Will they neither of them go?—Why do you loiter here, Sir Ge— (Coughs)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I muſt ſtay till the gentleman brings back my domino and maſk, you know. (Aſide) I'll not leave them.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) I am perſuaded it is he—Excuſe me, ſir: would you indulge me with the favour of your name?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My name, ſir! My name is—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aſide to Sir George) Huſh! Don't tell it!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane) Why not?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I inſiſt upon it!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay, then—My name, ſir, is a very pretty name. Pray what is yours?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) Yes, yes, it muſt be he—Have you any reaſon to be aſhamed of it?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir! Did you pleaſe to ſpeak? Upon my honor, you are a very polite pleaſant perſon.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) If I ſhould be miſtaken—I acknowledge, ſir, there is but one man, whoſe name I do but whoſe perſon I do not know, to whom that queſtion would not have been rude in the extreme. Should you not be that man, I aſk your pardon.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Should I not! Sir, that I may be ſure I am not, allow me to aſk his name?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: His name is—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Screams and ſinks on the chair) Oh!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Good Heavens!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What has happened?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Are you ill?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is it cramp, or ſpaſm?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Surely you have not broken a blood veſſel?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Shall I run for a phyſician?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Inſtantly.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I fly! Yet I muſt not leave you!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No delay, if you value my life.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Your life! I will go!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Detaining him) No, no.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I fly! I fly! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE VI. Enter LADY JANE'S woman.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Dear! my lady, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Lead me directly to my own room.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Shall I carry you?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No: only give me your arm, and come with me. I want to talk to you. I wiſh to hear what you have to ſay. (Aſide to her woman) When Sir George comes back, tell him I am partly recovered, but muſt not be diſturbed. It is my poſitive order.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) What does ſhe whiſper?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Stay—The Doctor may come in; but not Sir George. Mind, on your life, not Sir George!—Come, ſir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) This ſudden change is myſterious. Here is concealment.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Come, come.

div.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I purteſt, it has put me in ſuch a fluſter that I am quite all of a twitter!

div.stage: Enter SIR GEORGE followed by DR. GOSTERMAN.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Come along, Doctor! Make haſte Where is Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: In her own room.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is ſhe worſe?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: No, ſir; much better: but ſhe muſt not be diſturbed.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I muſt ſee her.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir, I can let nobody in but the Doctor.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why ſo? Is not the gentleman I left here now with her?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And I not admitted?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: On no account whatever.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He allowed, and I excluded! Indeed, I ſhall attend the Doctor.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Upon my honor, ſir, you muſt not.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Upon my honor, I will! My rival ſhall not eſcape me!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ha! De rifal! Ha, ha, ha! Dat is coot! De young fer dat vas mit Laty Shane vas make you ſhealouſy? Ha, ha, ha! Dat is coot! Bote dat is as noting at all. I ſhall tell you de ſometing myſtery. He vas no yentlemans. Ah ha! He vas a vomans.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A woman!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. He vas make acquaintance mit me, und I vas make acquaintance mit him; und he vas make faint, und I vas tie looſe de neck bandt, und den! Ah ha! I vas diſcober de mans vas a vomans!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ſair. I vas make aſtoniſh myſelf.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Won't you go to my lady, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Ya, my tear. Let me do. Laty Shane is fery pad; und I ſhall af de eſſence, und de cream, und de balſam, und de ſyrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable,
und de air, und de earſe, und de ſea, und all, &c. [Exit; gabbling.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I ſhould never have ſuſpected a woman! A ſtout, tall, robuſt figure! And for what purpoſe diſguiſe herſelf? That may be worth enquiry. I will wait and if poſſible have another look at the lady.

div.head: SCENE IX. Enter LORD VIBRATE, and MR. THOMPSON.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Two hundred and forty pounds! 'Tis a very large ſum, Mr. Thompſon.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: So large, my lord, that I have no means of paying it. I muſt languiſh out my life in a priſon.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No, Mr. Thompſon, no: you ſhall not do that. I will—And yet—Two hundred—A priſon—I don't know what to ſay. If I pay this money for you, I ſhall but encourage all around me to run in debt.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: It is a favour too great for me to hope.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You are a worthy man, and a priſon is a bad place—I—you—Pray what is your opinion, Sir George? Is it not dangerous for a man to have the character of being charitable?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No doubt, my lord! It is the very certain way for his houſe to be beſieged by beggars!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The maſter who pays the debts of one domeſtic makes himſelf the debtor of all the reſt.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
He changes a ſet of ſervants into a ſet
of duns! He firſt encourages them to be extravagant, and then makes it incumbent upon himſelf to pay for their follies and vices! He not only bribes them to be idle, and inſolent, but to waſte his property as well as their own!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: It is, as you ſay, a very ſerious caſe. I—I am ſorry for your misfortune, Mr. Thompſon—very ſorry—but—really—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Misfortune! What misfortune?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He has fooliſhly been bound for his ſiſter's huſband; and muſt go to priſon for the debt.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To priſon?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You have ſhewn me how dangerous it would be for me to interfere.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Very true: very true.—He has lived with your lordſhip ſeveral years?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He has; and I eſteem him highly.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A worthy man, whom it would be no diſgrace to call your friend?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: None. Still, however, conſequences muſt be weighed. I muſt take time to conſider. 'Tis folly to act in a hurry.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Very true—caution—caution—Is it a large ſum?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No leſs than two hundred and forty pounds!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Caution is a very excellent thing—Two hundred and forty—A fine virtue—Two—I would adviſe your lordſhip to it by all means—hundred and forty— (Looks round) Will you permit me juſt to write a ſhort memorandum: a bit of a note? (Goes to a table) I muſt ſend to a certain place. (Writes) Excuſe me a moment.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What can be done in this affair, Mr. Thompſon?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Nothing, my lord. I am reſigned. When I aſſiſted my brother, I did no more than my duty. Thoſe who lock me up in a priſon may, for aught I know, do theirs: yet, though they are at liberty and I ſhall be confined, I would neither change duties nor hearts with them. (Going.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Harkye! Harkye! Mr. Thompſon! Will you juſt deſire this to be taken as it is directed? (Aſide to him) Don't ſay a word: 'tis a draft on my banker. Diſcharge your debt; and be ſilent—You are very right, my lord: we cannot be too conſiderate; leſt, by miſtaken benevolence, we ſhould encourage vice.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Sir George! My lord!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why now will you not oblige me, Mr. Thompſon? Pray let that be delivered as it is directed. You ſurely will not deny me ſuch a favor—For you know, my lord, if we give—

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Indeed, I—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Will you begone? Will you begone? (Puſhes him kindly off▪ —If we give without—without—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Poor fellow! I ſuppoſe he is afraid of being taken.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! Is that it?—If we give, I ſay, with—too—Pſhaw! I have loſt the thread of my argument.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I muſt own, this is a dubious caſe. Perhaps I ought to pay the money. (Calls) Mr. Thompſon!—I don't think I ought to let him go to priſon. What ſhall I do, Sir George?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Whatever your lordſhip thinks beſt.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: But there is the difficulty!—Mr. Thompſon! He is gone. How fooliſh this is now! (As he is going off) Harry! Run after Mr. Thompſon, and call him back. One would think a man going to priſon would like me be wiſe enough to doubt, and take time to conſider of it.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Sir George, I am very angry. I have been waiting an age, expecting you would come and give your opinion on my maſquerade dreſs.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why did not your ladyſhip put it on?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: On, indeed? It has been on and off twenty times! I have ſent it to have ſome alteration. Beſide it is growing late: maſks will be calling in on you, in their way to the Opera-houſe, and you not at home to receive them!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I aſk ten thouſand pardons, but you know I am the moſt thoughtleſs creature on earth.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: So I would have you. Were you like the ſober punctual Mr. Delaval, I ſhould hate you. But then—

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: DELAVAL returning from LADY JANE'S apartment.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: (Aſide) Here the wretch comes!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) So, ſo! now I ſhall interrogate the lady. She has a very maſculine air! (Delaval bows to Lady Vibrate) A tolerable bow that, for a woman!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
(Aſide) He wiſhes, I ſuppoſe, to ſermonize
me: but I ſhall not give him an opportunity—Are you coming, Sir George?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) Ha!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I will follow your ladyſhip in a minute.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) I was right! It is he!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) She eyes me very ferociouſly!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I ſhall juſt call in upon you: or, if not, we ſhall meet afterward. I expect you to be very whimſical and ſatiric upon all my friends; ſo pray put on your beſt humour. Grave airs, you know, are my averſion. [Exit.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aſide) That was intended for me. Now for my gentleman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) She really has a very fierce look! A kind of threatening phyſiognomy; and would make no bad Grenadier.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I underſtand, your name is Sir George Verſatile?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) A baſs voice too!—At your ſervice, ſir; or madam; I really cannot tell which.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Cannot!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, I cannot upon my ſoul! (Aſide) A deviliſh black chin!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I have an account to ſettle with you, ſir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Have you? (Aſide) What the plague can ſhe mean?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: When can I find you at leiſure, and alone?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; alone.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Muſt this account then be privately ſettled, madam?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I beg your pardon! Sir, ſince you prefer it.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: If you know me, ſir, your inſolence is but a confirmation of the baſeneſs of your character!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I beg a million of pardons! I really do not know you.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Then, ſir, when you do, you will find cauſe to be a little more ſerious.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) What a Joan of Arc it is! There is danger ſhe ſhould knock me down.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Be pleaſed to name your time.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide) Zounds! She inſiſts upon a tête-à-téte!—I hope you will be kind enough to excuſe me, but I am juſt now ſo preſſed for time that I have not a moment to ſpare. Company is waiting. I muſt begone to the maſquerade. You I preſume are for the ſame place, and are ready dreſſed. I am your moſt obedient—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Seizing him) Sir, I inſiſt upon your naming an hour, to-morrow; and an early one.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why, what the plague!—Here muſt be ſome miſtake! Permit me to aſk, do you know Dr. Goſterman?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Was you not juſt now in danger of ſainting?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Faint? I faint!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It would I think be a very extraordinary thing! But ſo he told me: with other particulars.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Abſurd! Dr. Goſterman has not ſeen me for ſeveral months.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
He ſaid, ſir, you were a woman; and
perhaps, from that error, I may have unconſciouſly provoked you to behaviour which would elſe have been rather ſtrange. Have I given you any other offence?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; a mortal one.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mortal!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: And mortal muſt be the atonement.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: If ſo, the ſooner the better. Let it be immediately.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: No. I have ſerious concerns to ſettle. So have you! 'Tis time you ſhould think of things very different from maſquerading. Name your hour to-morrow morning; then, take an enemy's advice, retire to your cloſet, and make your will.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To whom am I indebted for this high menace, and this haughty warning? Your name, ſir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: That you ſhall know when next we meet: not before.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What age are you, ſir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Age!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Such peremptory heroes are not uſually long lived.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You are right, ſir; my life is probably doomed to be ſhort. But this is trifling. Name your hour.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: At ten to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The very time I could wiſh. I will be with you at your own houſe, inſorm you who I am, and, then—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So be it.— [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE XIII. Changes to the houſe of SIR GEORGE. A ſuite of apartments richly decorated and numerous maſks: ſome dancing; others paſſing and repaſſing.
div.stage: SIR GEORGE and LADY VIBRATE advance, unmaſked.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: What is the matter with you, Sir George? You are ſuddenly become as dull and almoſt as intolerable as my lord himſelf.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I own, I had ſomething on my ſpirits. But it is gone. Your ladyſhip's vivacity is an antidote to ſplenetic fits.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Oh, if you are ſubject to fits of the ſpleen, I renounce you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, no! Heigho! Ha, ha, ha! Let me go merrily down the dance of life!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ay! or I will not be your partner.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: As for recollections, retroſpective anxieties, and painful thoughts, I I I hate them. They ſhall not trouble me. For if a man, you know, were to be ſprung on a mine to-morrow, ha, ha, ha! it were folly to let that trouble him to-day.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sprung on a mine? You talk wildly!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: True. I am a wild unaccountable non deſcript. I am any thing, every thing, and ſoon may be—

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nothing. Strange events are poſſible; and poſſible events are ſtrange.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Come, come, caſt off this diſagreeable humour; and join the maſks.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
With all my heart. A maſk is an excellent
utenſil; and may be worn with a naked face.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: (Retiring) Why don't you come? You uſed to be all compliance.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So I fear I always ſhall be. 'Tis my worſt virtue. Call it a vice, if you pleaſe; and perhaps it is even then my worſt.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I really do not comprehend you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No wonder. Man is an incomprehenſible animal! But no matter for that. We will be merry ſtill ſay I—at leaſt till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: (Joins the maſks) Yonder is Lady Jane.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay then, I am on the wing!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: (Advancing) Whither?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ah! Have I found you again? So much the better! I have been thinking of you this half hour.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Ay? That muſt have been a prodigious effort!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: To think of one perſon for ſo great a length of time.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: True. Were you my bittereſt enemy, you could not have uttered a more galling truth. I am glad I have met with you, however.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: So am I. 'Tis my errand here.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You now, I hope, will let me ſee your face?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I might, perhaps, were it but poſſible to ſee your heart.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, no: that cannot be. I have no heart.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So am I. But come, I wiſh to be better acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And I wiſh you to be better acquainted with yourſelf. You know not half your own good qualities.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! My good qualities? Heigho!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Your fame is gone abroad! Your gallantry, your free humour, your frolics in England and Italy, your—Apropos: I am told, Lady Jane is captivated by the ardour and delicacy of your paſſion! Is it true?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Are you an inquiſitor?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Are you afraid of inquiſitors?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You may. Keep me no longer in this ſuſpenſe. Let me know who you are?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: An old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Of mine?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Of one who was formerly your friend.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Whom do you mean?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: You muſt have been a man of uncommon worth; for I have heard him beſtow ſuch praiſes upon you that my heart has palpitated if your name was but mentioned!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Of whom are you talking?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Lord! that you ſhould be ſo forgetful! That can only have happened ſince you became a perſon of faſhion: for no man once remembered his friends better. It is true, they were then uſeful to you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir, I—Be warned! Purſue this no farther.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p:
You little ſuſpected at that time you were on the eve of being a wealthy baronet. Oh
no! And to ſee how kind and grateful you were to thoſe who loved you! No one would have believed you could ſo ſoon have become a perfect man of the mode; and with ſo polite and eaſy an indifference ſo entirely have forgotten all your old acquaintance! I dare ſay you ſcarcely remember the late Colonel Delaval.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: His daughter too has utterly ſlipped your memory?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I inſiſt on knowing who you are!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: How different it was when, your merit neglected, your ſpirits depreſſed, and your poverty deſpiſed, you groaned under the oppreſſion of an unjuſt and ſelfiſh world! How did your drooping ſpirits revive by the foſtering ſmiles of the man who firſt noticed you, took you to his houſe and heart, and adopted you as his ſon! Poor Maria! Silly girl, to love as ſhe did! Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: This is not to be endured!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: What was her offence? You became a baronet! Ay! True, that was her crime. Yet, when your fortunes were low, it was not imputed to you as guilt.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Damnation!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p:
Are your new friends more affectionate than your old? Fortune ſmiles, and ſo do they. Poor Maria! Has Lady Jane ever heard her name? Will you invite her to your wedding? (Her voice continually faltering.) Do. She ſhould have been your bride: then let her be your bride maid—She is greatly altered—She will be leſs beautiful—now—than her fair rival. Her birth is not quite ſo high—but—if a—heart—a heart—
a heart— (Struggling with her feelings ſinks into Sir George's arms, and her maſk falls off)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Heavens and earth! 'Tis ſhe! Help! 'Tis Maria! Who waits?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Help! Help!—Salts! Hartſhorn!—Water! Help!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Bleſs me! This lady again.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is ſhe then known to you?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No! Who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Quick! Quick!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Nay but, tell me?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I cannot! Muſt not!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Muſt not?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Dare not!—She revives; and, to my confuſion, will ſoon tell you herſelf. Maria! Are you better, Maria?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am very faint.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: My carriage is at the door. Will you truſt yourſelf to me?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh yes. I am weak—Very weak, and very fooliſh! But I ſhall not long diſturb your happineſs. I hope ſoon to be paſt that.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Paſt! Oh Maria!—I—have no utterance—Lady Jane, you will preſently know of me what to know of myſelf is—Oh!—No matter. Not then for my ſake but for pity, for the love of ſuffering virtue, be careful of this lady; whom when you know, as ſoon you muſt, you will deſpiſe and abhor the lunatic, the wretch, that could—Maria—I—I— [Exit abruptly.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: What is the matter? Any accident? Was not that Sir George?—Good God! My ſiſter!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Your ſiſter!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: How comes this? Why this dreſs? And with that apoſtate! that wretch! Speak, Maria!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, be more temperate. Your ſiſter's ſpirits and health ought not to be trifled with by your violence. I do not know, though I think I gueſs, her ſtory. I hope you have a brother's tenderneſs for her?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: That ſhall be ſhortly ſeen. A few hours will ſhew how dear ſhe is to my heart.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I fear you cheriſh bad paſſions: ſuch as I never can love, and never will ſhare.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Well, well, Lady Jane, that is not to be argued now. I am a man, and ſubject to the miſtakes of man. There are feelings which can and feelings which cannot be ſubdued. I muſt run my courſe, and take all conſequences.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh God! In what will they end?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No more of this, Mr. Delaval. Come with me: lead your ſiſter to my carriage. She ſhall be under my care. She can inſpire thoſe ſympathies which your too ſtubborn temper ſeems to deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed, you wrong me! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. MARIA in her proper dreſs, LADY JANE and LUCY, FOOTMEN waiting. Breakfaſt equipage on the table.

sp.speaker: LADY JANE.
sp.p: REMOVE thoſe things. We have done.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: What is it o'clock?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Juſt ſtruck ten, ma'am.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Lady Vibrate is a ſad rake! She did not leave the maſquerade till five this morning.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And Sir George not there!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: After the diſcovery of laſt night, could you ſuppoſe he would be ſeen revelling at ſuch a place?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I dread another and more horrible cauſe! My brother!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, you know, ſlept in this houſe.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But he has been out theſe two hours!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: What then, ma'am? Is not Mr. Williams on the watch? You know, ma'am, you may truſt Mr. Williams with your life.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: If all were ſafe, he would be back.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Pray calm your ſpirits.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but Mr. Williams muſt have been here before this, if ſomething fatal had not happened!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I am ſure, ma'am, you frighten me to death!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aſide) Her terrors are but too well founded!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Footſteps without) What noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Bleſs me!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: See who it is!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (After opening the door) Law, ma'am! I declare it is Mr. Williams!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Williams! Every thing is right: is not it? All is as it ſhould be?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: That is more than I know.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Why then the worſt is paſt.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: No, ma'am: I can't ſay that, either.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Nay but, what news do you bring? Speak.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why you know my maſter laſt night made enquiries how to find the chambers of Counſellor Demur: ſo, when he went out this morning, I obſerved your directions and followed him. He went to the Counſellor's, in Lincoln's Inn; and there I left him and hurried away to Sir George's, to enquire and hear all I could: though it was rather unlucky that I was not acquainted in the family.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Did not you make uſe of my name?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Oh yes, my lady. Beſide, ſervants your ladyſhip knows are not ſo ſuſpicious as their maſters: they ſoon become friendly together: ſo in five minutes Sir George's valet and I were on as intimate a footing as we could wiſh.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And what did he ſay? Tell me.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why, ma'am, he ſaid that Sir George did not leave his own houſe laſt night, after the fainting of the young gentleman.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That was you, you know, ma'am.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p:
And, what is more, that he did not go to bed; but walked up and down the room till
daylight in the morning; and then called I don't know how often to warn the ſervants that he ſhould not be at home to any body whatever, except to a ſtrange gentleman.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why yes, ma'am, according to the deſcription, it could be nobody elſe.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: And at what hour was Mr. Delaval to be there?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aſide) Zooks! I forgot to aſk—That, that, my lady, I did not learn. So, this being all the ſervants told me, I ran poſt haſte to make my report to you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: The worſt I foreboded will happen!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What can be done?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Perhaps it will be beſt for me to go back to Sir George's, wait for the arrival of my maſter, and, if he ſhould come, haſten away as faſt as I can to inform you of it.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That is a good thought, Mr. Williams! Is not it, madam? A very good thought, indeed! Don't you think it is, my lady?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I know not what we can do better.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Nay but, while Williams is bringing us the intelligence, every thing we moſt dread may happen.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Dear! So it may!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Suppoſe then, madam, I ſhould ſtay at my poſt; and diſpatch Sir George's valet to you with the news?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Well, that is the beſt thought of all! I am ſure you will own it is, madam.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: We muſt reſolve; or, while we are deliberating—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Merciful God! Run, Williams! Fly! Save my brother! Save Sir George!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Succeed but in this, and command all we have to give.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I will do my beſt.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That I am ſure he will. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. Changes to the houſe of SIR GEORGE.—SIR GEORGE walking in perturbation of mind. After ſome time he looks at his watch.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He will ſoon be here—Five minutes—but five minutes and then— (Walks again, throws himſelf on a ſofa, takes up a book, toſſes it away and riſes) What is man's firſt duty? To be happy. Short ſighted fool! The happineſs of this hour is the miſery of the next! (Again walks and looks at his watch) What is life? A tiſſue of follies! Inconſiſtencies! Joys that make reaſon weep, and ſorrows at which wiſdom ſmiles. Pſhaw! There is not between ape and oyſter ſo ridiculous or ſo wretched a creature as man. (Walks) Oh Maria! (Again conſulting his watch) I want but a few ſeconds. My watch perhaps is too faſt. (Rings)

div.stage: Enter Footman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Has nobody yet been here?

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis the time to a minute. (Loud knocking) Fly! If it be the perſon I have deſcribed, admit him. [Exit Footman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Now let the thunder ſtrike!

div.head: SCENE IV. DELAVAL introduced. They ſalute.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Good morning, ſir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You recollect me?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I have been anxious for your coming. Your menace lives in my memory; and I ſhall be glad to know the name of him who has threatened ſuch mortal enmity.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: A little patience will be neceſſary. I muſt preface my proceedings with a ſhort ſtory.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I ſhall be all attention. Pleaſe to be ſeated. Wave ceremony, and to the ſubject— (They ſit) Now, ſir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: About ſix years ago, a certain youth came up from college; poor, and unprotected. He was a ſcholar, pleaſing in manner, warm and generous of temper, of a reſpectable family, and ſeemed to poſſeſs the germ of every virtue.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well, ſir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Hear me on: my praiſes will not be tedious. Chance made him known to a man who deſired to cheriſh his good qualities; and the purſe, the experience, and the power of his benefactor, ſuch as they were, he profited by to the utmoſt. Received as a ſon, he ſoon became dear to the family: but moſt dear to the daughter of his friend; whoſe tender age and glowing affections made her apt to admire the virtues ſhe heard her father ſo ardently praiſe, and encourage. You are uneaſy?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Be pleaſed to continue.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
The aſſiduities of the youth to gain her
heart were unabating; and his pretenſions, poor and unknown as he then was, were not rejected. The noble nature of his friend ſcorned to make his poverty his crime. Why do you bite your lip? Was it not generous?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Firmly) Was it not?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Certainly! Nothing could—equal the—generoſity.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The health of his benefactor was declining faſt; and the only thing required of the youth was that he ſhould qualify himſelf for the cares of life, by ſome profeſſion. He therefore entered a ſtudent in the Temple; and the means were furniſhed by his protector, till the end was obtained. Was not this friendſhip?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The lady, almoſt a child when firſt he knew her, increaſed in grace and beauty faſter than in years. Sweetneſs and ſmiles played upon her countenance. She was the delight of her friends, the admiration of the world, and the coveted of every eye. Lovers of fortune and faſhion contended for her hand: but ſhe had beſtowed her heart—had beſtowed it on a—Sit ſtill, ſir; I ſhall ſoon have done. I am coming to the point. Five years elapſed; during which the youth received every kindneſs friendſhip could afford, and every proof chaſte affection had to give. Theſe he returned with promiſes and proteſtations that ſeemed too vaſt for his heart. I would ſay for his tongue—Are you unwell, ſir?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Go on with your tale.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
His benefactor, feeling the hand of death ſteal on, was anxious to ſee the two perſons deareſt
to his heart happy before he expired; and the marriage was determined on, the day fixed, and the friends of the family invited. The intended bridegroom appeared half frantic with his approaching bliſs. Now, ſir, mark his proceeding. In this ſhort interval, by ſudden and unexpected deaths, he becomes the heir to a title and large eſtate. Well! Does he not fly to the arms of his languiſhing friend? Does he not pour his new treaſures and his tranſports into the lap of love? Coward and monſter!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Both ſtarting up) Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Viler than words can paint! Having robbed a family of honor, a friend of peace, and an angel of every human ſolace, he fled, like a thief, and concealed himſelf from immediate contempt and vengeance in a foreign country. But contempt and vengeance have at length overtaken him: they beſet him: they face him at this inſtant. The friend he wronged is dead: but the ſon of that friend lives, and I am he.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis as I thought!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You are—I will not defile my lips by telling you what you are.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I own that what I have done—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Forbear to interrupt me, ſir. You have nothing to plead, and much to hear. Firſt ſay, did my ſiſter, by any improper conduct, levity of behaviour, or fault or vice whatever, give you juſt cauſe to abandon her?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: None! None! Her purity is only exceeded by her love.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
Then how, barbarian, how had you the heart to diſgrace the family and endanger the life of a woman whoſe ſanctified affection would have
embraced you in poverty, peſtilence, or death; and who, had ſhe poſſeſſed empires, would have beſtowed them with an imperial affection?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir, if you aſk, Have I committed errors? call them crimes if you will, Yes. If you demand, Will I juſtify them? No. If you require me to atone for them, here is my heart: you have wrongs to revenge, ſtrike; and, if you can, inflict a pang greater than any it yet has known.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Juſtice is not to be diſarmed by being braved. To the queſtion. It can be no part of your intention, and certainly not of mine, that you ſhould marry my ſiſter. Something very different muſt be done.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What? Name it?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You muſt give me an acknowledgment, written and ſigned by yourſelf, that you have baſely and moſt diſhonorably injured, inſulted and betrayed Maria Delaval: and this paper, immediately as I leave your houſe, I ſhall publiſh in every poſſible way; till my ſiſter ſhall be ſo appeaſed, and honor ſo ſatiated, that vengeance itſelf ſhall cry, Hold!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Written by me! Publiſhed! No. I will ſign no ſuch paper.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
So I ſuppoſed; and the alternative follows. Here I am: nor will I quit you, go where you will, till you ſhall conſent to retire with me to ſome place from which one of us muſt never return. Should I be the victor, flight, baniſhment from my native country, and the bittereſt recollections of the villanies of man, muſt be the fate of me and my ſiſter. If I fall, you then may triumph and ſhe languiſh and die unrevenged. This,
or the written acknowledgment. Conſider, and chuſe.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What can I anſwer? The paper you ſhall not have. My life you are welcome to: take it.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Have you not brought diſgrace enough on my family? Would you make me an aſſaſſin? My ſiſter and my father loved you. Let me, if poſſible, feel ſome little return of reſpect for you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Having wronged the ſiſter, would you have me murder the brother? Already the moſt guilty of men, would you make me the worſt of fiends? Though an enemy, be a generous one.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Plauſible ſophiſt! The paper, ſir: or, man to man and arm to arm, cloſe the ſcene of my diſhonor, or your own. The written acknowledgment. Determine. (Walks away and views the pictures)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Apart) Why, ay! 'Tis come home! I have ſought it, deſerved it, 'tis fallen, and the rock muſt cruſh the reptile!—Then welcome ruin. The ſword muſt decide. (Goes to take his ſword, but ſtops) The ſword? What! Betray the ſiſter and aſſaſſinate the brother? Oh God! And ſuch a brother! Stern, but noble minded: indignant of injury, peerleſs in affection, and proud of a ſiſter whom the world might worſhip; but whom I, worthleſs wretch, in levity and pride of heart, have abandoned. (Aloud) Mr. Delaval!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Have you reſolved to ſign?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Hear me.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The written acknowledgment!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
My behaviour to your ſiſter is—what I cannot endure to name—'Tis hateful! 'Tis—infamous!
My obligations to your moſt excellent father, the reſpect you have inſpired me with, and my love for Maria—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Inſolent! Inſufferable meanneſs! The paper, Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Angry though you are, Mr. Delaval, you muſt hear me. I ſay, my love, my adoration of Maria has but increaſed my guilt. It has made me dread her contempt. I durſt not face the angel whom I had ſo deeply injured.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Artifice! Evaſion! Cowardice!—Your ſignature!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Snatching up his ſword from the table) You ſhall have it. Follow me.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Stopping ſhort) Hold, Mr. Delaval. Juſtice is on your ſide. If your firmneſs be not a ſavage ſpirit of revenge, if you do not thirſt for blood, you will feel my only reſource will be to fall on your ſword. I cannot lift my arm againſt you.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Then ſign the acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Can you in the ſpirit even of an enemy aſk it? Do you not already deſpiſe me enough? Think for a moment: am I the only man that ever erred? Is it ſo wonderful that a giddy youth, whoſe habitual failing was compliance, by ſudden accident elevated to the pinnacle of fortune, ſurrounded by proud and ſelfiſh relations of whoſe approbation I was vain, is it ſo ſtrange that I ſhould be overpowered by their dictates, and yield to their intreaties? Your friendſhip or my death is now the only alternative. Suppoſe the latter: will it honor you among men? At the man of blood the heart of man revolts! Will it endear you to
Maria? Kind forgiving angel, and hateful to myſelf as her affection makes me, I laſt night found that affection ſtill as ſtrong, ſtill as pure, as in the firſt hour of our infant loves. Lady Jane—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Forbear to name her! 'Tis profanation from your lips! No more caſuiſtry! No ſubterfuge! The paper!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Can no motives—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: None!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My future life, my ſoul, ſhall be devoted to Maria.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The paper!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Obdurate man! (Reflects a moment) You ſhall have it. (Goes to the table to write, during which Delaval remains deep in thought and much agitated) Here, ſir! ſince you will not be generous, let me be juſt. 'Tis proper I remove every taint of ſuſpicion from the deeply wronged Maria.

p.q: I George Verſatile, once poor and dependent, ſince vain fickle and faithleſs, do under my hand acknowledge I have perfidiouſly—broken my pledged promiſe—to the moſt deſerving—lovely—and
p.stage: (Begins in much agitation to tear the paper.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Damn it—I can't—I can't ſpeak. Here! Here! (Striking his boſom.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Falls on his neck) Can it be? My friend!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: This ſtubborn temper—always in extremes! The tiger, or the child.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh no! 'Twas not to be forgiven! Beſt of men!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Well, well: we are friends.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Everlaſtingly! Brothers!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes; brothers.

div.head: SCENE V. Enter WILLIAMS in great haſte.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, but Lady Jane and your ſiſter are below. They inſiſt on coming up, and the ſervants are afraid to—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Maria! Let us fly! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VI. The apartments of LORD VIBRATE.
div.stage: LADY VIBRATE and the DOCTOR.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my coot laty: dat vas efery vordt ſo true as vat I ſay. I vas diſcober it vas a vomans; und Sair Shorge, und my Laty Shane, und de vaiting vomans vas diſcober to me all as vat I ſay more.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ay, ay! That was the reaſon Sir George was not at the maſquerade.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I obſerved he was in a ſtrange moody humour.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Lordt Fiprate vas fery moſh amazement, ven I vas make him diſcober all as vat I vas make diſcober mit my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sir George has behaved very improperly.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p:
So, ſo, ſo! All I foreboded has come to paſs! The day is ſlipped away, a new one is
here, and every poſſibility of recovering the eſtate is gone!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Do you laugh?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I do, indeed!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is your daughter's loſs the ſubject of your mirth?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No, no; not her loſs, but your poſitive determination to prove I did not know you! Ha, ha, ha! When I told you that even that motive would not be ſtrong enough, how you ſtormed! "But it will, my lady! But it won't, my lord! I ſay it will, my lady! I ſay it won't, my lord!" Ha, ha, ha! Will you believe that I know you now?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? Adviſe me, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I vas adfice, my coot Lordt, dat you ſhall do efery ting as vat you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ay, think: aſk advice. Ha, ha, ha! Now that you can do nothing, the enquiry will be very amuſing.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Well, Thompſon, what ſays Counſellor Demur? Has the time abſolutely elapſed?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Abſolutely, my lord.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: How wiſely your lordſhip doubts, before you decide! Hay, Doctor?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I have good news, nevertheleſs.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Good news? Speak! Of what kind?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The honeſty of the oppoſite party.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, the holder of the land?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Which way? Explain!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: He has engaged to Mr. Demur, I being preſent, that, if your lordſhip will only ſhew the legality of your late title, he will reſign the eſtate.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: It cannot be! The laſt purchaſer is in India.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The laſt purchaſer is dead; and it has deſcended to one whom you, my lord and lady, little ſuſpect to be its poſſeſſor.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval reſign it on exhibiting the legality of my title?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: He will, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did he make no conditions?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, did he not mention Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Her name did eſcape his lips; but riſing paſſion, and, if I rightly read his heart, emotions of the moſt delicate ſenſibility immediately cloſed them: as if he would not endure the love he bore her to be profaned by any the ſlighteſt ſemblance of barter and ſale.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What do you ſay to that, Lady Vibrate? What do you ſay to that?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: The proceeding is honorable, I own.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did I not always tell you Mr. Delaval was a man of honor?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You tell me, my lord? Why you were going to challenge him yeſterday morning!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He is no ſuch weathercock as your favorite, Sir George.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You miſtake: Sir George is no favorite of mine. Is he, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yuſt as vat you ſay, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, he did not come to make a buffoon of himſelf, for your diverſion, at the maſquerade laſt night! Hay, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yuſt as vat you ſay, my coot lordt.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: His perfidious treatment of Miſs Delaval is unpardonable.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas pad! Fery pad, inteet!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay ay! He has plenty of words, but he has no heart.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is pad! Fery pad inteet!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord: Sir George may have committed miſtakes, but to the goodneſs of his heart I am a witneſs.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: By his benevolence, I was yeſterday relieved from the diſgrace and the horrors of a priſon.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: He paid a debt, which, had I been confined, I never could have diſcharged; and, for this unexpected act of humanity, he would not ſuffer ſo much as my thanks.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did Sir George pay the two hundred and forty pounds, Mr. Thompſon?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The note, which he pretended to write and ſend by me, was a draft on his banker for three hundred.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why he confirmed all my arguments againſt it; and added twice as many of his own.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Sair Shorge vas alvay make agréable. Dat vas his vay.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I own, however, I am ſtill more ſurpriſed at the unexampled generoſity of Mr. Delaval.

div.head: SCENE IX. Enter WILLIAMS.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Where is your maſter, Mr. Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: They are all coming, my lady.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Who is coming?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, Lady Jane, Miſs Delaval, and Sir George. There has been ſad work! But it is all over, and they are now ſo happy! Here they are!

div.stage: SCENE THE LAST. Enter Mr. DELAVAL leading LADY JANE, and SIR GEORGE with MARIA, followed by LUCY.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, I have great obligations to you. Thompſon has been telling me of your diſintereſted equity.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The obligation, my lord, was mine. Your lordſhip well knows that the firſt of obligations is to be juſt.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Well, well; but the eſtate you are ſo willing to reſign will ſtill, I hope, be yours.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Nay, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Dubious as all things are, that is a ſubject on which I proteſt I do not believe I ſhall ever have any doubts. What ſay you, Lady Jane? (Irony) But now I have my doubts again.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Eagerly) What doubts, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I doubt whether you underſtand me?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Would your lordſhip teach me to diſſemble?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Um—I doubt whether that would be much for your good.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I hope Lady Vibrate will not oppoſe our union?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No, Mr. Delaval. Your laſt generous action has charmed me; and Sir George—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Has declined in your good opinion. But you cannot think ſo ill of me as I do of myſelf; and, if ever again I ſhould recover my own ſelf reſpect, I ſhall be indebted for it to this beſt of men, and to this moſt incomparable and affectionate of women!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My preſent joys are inexpreſſible!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Which my impetuous indignation threatened▪ for ever to deſtroy. (Comes forward) How dangerous are extremes! Sometimes we doubt, and indeciſion is our bane: at others, hurried away by the ſudden impulſe of paſſion, our courſe is marked with miſery. One man is too compliant: another too intractable. Yet happineſs is the aim of all. Since then all are ſo liable to be miſled, let gentle forbearance, indulgent thoughts, and a mild forgiving ſpirit, be ever held as the ſacred duties of man to man.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: SPOKEN BY MR. QUICK, AND MRS. MATTOCKS.
div.stage: (As Mr Pope concludes and is preparing to low to the audience, Mr Quick with ſome importance comes forward.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: HOLD, Mr. Pope! Pleaſe to give place to me:
'Tis my part to conclude the comedy.
Hem! Hem! (Begins a grave and ſtately how.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: (Eagerly advancing.) Yours, Mr. Quick? I beg you'll hold your tongue!
All Epilogues of right to me belong.
You teaſe the audience, ſir; and put me out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: Teaſe? Humph! Permit me, madam, there to doubt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: Your part is over, now; your doubts are ended.

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: Would that they were! (To the audience.) Say, friends, are you offended?
Or are you pleas'd? Which way do you incline?
The author has his doubts; and I have mine;
Pronounce our doom: relieve us from our pain!

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: (Laughs.) Look at thoſe diſmal features and refrain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: Should it be fatal, hear, oh hear, our pleadings!
Grant an arreſt of judgment: ſtay proceedings:
I move the court—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: You move? Stand back! I'll wait no longer.
I tell you once again I am th' Epilogue monger.

div.stage: (Surveys him and laughs)

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: What do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: You! There's reaſon ample▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: (Retiring.) I beg, ſirs, you'll not follow her example.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: The hypocrite! Well, well, I'm glad he's gone:
For now the pleadings will be all my own.
The author hopes I'll advocate his play.
Heaven help the man! What would he have me ſay?
Something about the anxious months he ſpent,
His garret traverſing his brain intent
On this, and that, and t'other; action, plot,
Wit, humour, paſſion; and the lord knows what!
And tell how difficult it was to write
The charming nonſenſe you have heard to-night!—
Poor fool! When he ſuppos'd his work complete,
He thought he had achiev'd a mighty feat!
Nay he proteſts that earth and heaven he'd move,
Could he but pen what you might well approve.
The man ſpeaks fair; is tolerably civil:
Then, ſince an author's only a poor devil,
Doom him to what will give us all delight:
Make him repeat his follies every night.
